THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard Hancock,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Wal-Mart Stores, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3645
Submitted March 10, 2003 - Filed June 
  2, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert E. Lee, Matthew N. Tyler, Amy Anderson Wise, of Florence; 
  for Appellant.
Ronald B. Diegel, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

MOREHEAD, A.J.:Â  Richard Hancock was injured 
  while working for his employer on Wal-Martâ€™s premises.Â  Hancock filed suit in 
  the circuit court, alleging his injuries were the result of Wal-Martâ€™s negligence.Â  
  The trial judge granted Wal-Martâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding workersâ€™ 
  compensation was Hancockâ€™s exclusive remedy.Â  Hancock appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Tru-Wheels, Inc., one of Wal-Martâ€™s vendors, 
  employed Hancock.Â  Tru-Wheels provided Wal-Mart with individuals to assemble 
  and set up Wal-Mart merchandise in the store.Â Â  Hancock assembled merchandise 
  exclusively for Wal-Mart.Â  On a typical day, Hancock would report to the Wal-Mart 
  manager and receive instructions about which items to assemble.Â  Hancock assembled 
  the items on the Wal-Mart premises and would report any problems to the applicable 
  Wal-Mart department manager.Â  Hancock was injured when, in the course of assembling 
  riding lawnmowers, a Wal-Mart employee ran over his foot with a forklift.Â  
Hancock filed suit in the circuit court, 
  alleging his injuries were the result of Wal-Martâ€™s negligence.Â  Wal-Mart filed 
  a motion for summary judgment, arguing Hancock was a statutory employee and 
  thus had workersâ€™ compensation as his exclusive remedy.Â  The trial judge granted 
  the motion, finding Hancock was limited to a workersâ€™ compensation claim because 
  he was Wal-Martâ€™s statutory employee. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate where 
  there is no genuine issue of material fact and it is clear the moving party 
  is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  However, 
  summary judgment is not appropriate where there is no dispute as to the facts 
  but the parties dispute the inferences to be drawn from the undisputed facts.Â  
  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  

â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment 
  motion, this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court.â€Â  
  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  â€œOn appeal 
  from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all 
  ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in 
  a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€Â  Id.
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Agreement
Hancock argues the trial judge erred in granting 
  summary judgment without first reviewing the agreement between Tru-Wheels and 
  Wal-Mart.Â  
While Hancock raised this argument before the trial 
  judge, it was not addressed in the final order.Â  Despite this omission, Hancock 
  did not file a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), 
  SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for review by this Court.Â  
  See Fraternal Order of Police v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 
  332 S.C. 496, 501, 506 S.E.2d 495, 497 (1998) (holding argument on appeal not 
  preserved even where raised to the circuit court because â€œthat court failed 
  to rule on the issue and [appellants] failed to call this omission to the circuit 
  courtâ€™s attention in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motionâ€); Noisette v. Ismail, 
  304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding issue was not preserved 
  for appellate review where the trial judge did not explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s 
  argument and the appellant made no Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment).Â  
  Regardless, Hancock does not succeed on the merits of this argument.
Hancock submitted an affidavit from the 
  manager of the Wal-Mart store where the accident occurred.Â  The affidavit states 
  â€œWal-Mart has an agreement with Tru-Wheels, Inc. wherein Tru-Wheels, Inc. provides 
  workers to set up and assemble various items of merchandise which are sold by 
  Wal-Mart.â€Â  Hancock argued at the summary judgment hearing that he had never 
  received a copy of the aforementioned agreement, and asked the court to order 
  Wal-Mart to produce the agreement.Â  Wal-Mart countered there was only an oral 
  agreement between Wal-Mart and Tru-Wheels.Â  Â Â 
There is no evidence in the record that a written agreement 
  existed between Wal-Mart and Tru-Wheels.Â  Hancock is merely arguing that the 
  Wal-Mart managerâ€™s use of the word â€œagreementâ€ implied there was a written formalization 
  of the labor arrangement between Wal-Mart and Tru-Wheels.Â  However, there are 
  no exhibits, testimony, affidavits, or evidence to support this contention.Â  
  Accordingly, even viewing this argument in the light most favorable to Hancock, 
  we find the trial judge did not err in granting Wal-Martâ€™s motion for summary 
  judgment.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Statutory Employee
Hancock argues the trial judge erred in finding 
  he was Wal-Martâ€™s statutory employee.Â  Specifically, he contends the product 
  that Tru-Wheels delivered to Wal-Mart was Hancockâ€™s labor, and the â€œmere delivery 
  of this fungible commodity does not mean Tru Wheels was involved in part of 
  Wal-Martâ€™s business.â€Â  Instead, the relationship was between a vendor of labor 
  and its customer.Â  As such, Hancock asserts he was not Wal-Martâ€™s statutory 
  employee. 
Coverage under the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act depends on the existence of an employer-employee relationship.Â  McDowell 
  v. Stilley Plywood Co., 210 S.C. 173, 41 S.E.2d 872 (1947).Â Â  â€œSouth Carolina 
  courts have repeatedly held that determination of the employer-employee relationship 
  for workersâ€™ compensation purposes is jurisdictional. Consequently, this Court 
  has the power and duty to review the entire record and decide the jurisdictional 
  facts in accord with the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Glass v. Dow Chem. 
  Co., 325 S.C. 198, 201-02, 482 S.E.2d 49, 51 (1997).Â  
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act sets forth the circumstances 
  that can give rise to a statutory employment relationship.

When any person, in this section and Â§Â§ 42-1-420 and 42-1-430 
  referred to as â€œowner,â€ undertakes to perform or execute any work which is part 
  of his trade, business or occupation and contracts with any other person (in 
  this section and Â§Â§ 42-1-420 to 42-1-450 referred to as â€œsubcontractorâ€) for 
  the execution or performance by or under such subcontractor of the whole or 
  any part of the work undertaken by such owner, the owner shall be liable to 
  pay to any workman employed in the work any compensation under this Title which 
  he would have been liable to pay if the workman had been immediately employed 
  by him.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-400 (1985).Â  â€œIf a worker 
  is properly classified as a statutory employee, his sole remedy for work-related 
  injuries is to seek relief under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act; he may not maintain 
  a negligence cause of action against his direct employer or his statutory employer.â€Â  
  Neese v. Michelin Tire Corp., 324 S.C. 465, 472, 478 S.E.2d 91, 94 (Ct. 
  App. 1996), overruled on other grounds by Abbott v. The Limited, Inc., 
  338 S.C. 161, 164 n.1, 526 S.E.2d 513, 514 n.1 (2000).Â Â Â Â  
To determine whether an employee is engaged in 
  an activity that is part of the ownerâ€™s trade, business, or occupation as required 
  under section 42-1-400, this Court has applied the following three tests:Â  â€œ(1) 
  is the activity an important part of the ownerâ€™s business or trade; (2) is the 
  activity a necessary, essential, and integral part of the ownerâ€™s business; 
  or (3) has the activity previously been performed by the ownerâ€™s employees?â€Â  
  Meyer v. Piggly Wiggly No. 24, Inc., 338 S.C. 471, 473, 527 S.E.2d 761, 
  763 (2000).Â  â€œOnly one of these three tests need be met but there is no easily 
  applied formula and each case must be decided on its own facts.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œ[T]he guidepost is whether or not that which is being done is or is not a part 
  of the general trade, business or occupation of the owner.â€Â  Hopkins v. Darlington 
  Veneer Co., 208 S.C. 307, 311, 38 S.E.2d 4, 6 (1946).
 In Meyer, the claimant was employed 
  by a wholesale bakery that was, in turn, a vendor for a grocery store.Â  Claimantâ€™s 
  duties were to stock the shelves with the vendorâ€™s products and clean the display.Â  
  When claimant slipped and fell in the grocery store, he filed an action in tort.Â  
  The Supreme Court concluded claimant was not the grocery storeâ€™s statutory employee 
  because his activities on the storeâ€™s premises were â€œrelated only to the sale 
  of [v]endorâ€™s goods and were insubstantial in the context of [the grocery storeâ€™s] 
  general business.â€Â  Meyer, 338 S.C. at 474, 527 S.E.2d at 763.
We find the facts of the instant case do not point 
  to such a vendor/vendee relationship.Â  Although Hancock characterized the relationship 
  as vendor/vendee, that alone is not controlling in the statutory employment 
  analysis.Â  See Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, Ltd., 337 S.C. 
  313, 322, 523 S.E.2d 766, 770 (1999) (â€œWhatever the parties contract to call 
  their relationship is not controlling in a statutory employment analysis.â€).Â  
  Rather, Hancockâ€™s relationship with Wal-Mart satisfies all three of the Meyer 
  tests and thus fits the description of a statutory employee.Â  
In terms of the first test, the Wal-Mart manager, in his 
  affidavit, stated Hancockâ€™s duties were a â€œvital and important part of Wal-Martâ€™s 
  business in that items always display and sell better once they have been assembled.â€Â  
  As to the second test, the manager also stated Hancockâ€™s duties were â€œa vital 
  and integral part of [Wal-Martâ€™s] regular operations.â€ Â Hancockâ€™s deposition 
  testimony supports this statement.Â  On a regular basis, Hancock assembled merchandise 
  exclusively for Wal-Mart at the store.Â  When he arrived at the store, Hancock 
  reported to a Wal-Mart department manager who, in turn, identified the merchandise 
  that was to be assembled.Â  Hancock then went to the assembly area where he waited 
  for the department employees to bring him the boxes.Â  Upon completion of his 
  assigned merchandise, Hancock informed the department manager and turned in 
  his itemized work order. Â Regarding the third test, both the Wal-Mart manager 
  and Hancock stated that Wal-Mart employees often performed the same assembly 
  duties as Hancock.Â  Therefore, under the Meyer analysis, Hancock was 
  Wal-Martâ€™s statutory employee, and workersâ€™ compensation is the sole remedy 
  for his injuries.Â  See Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 
  S.C. 416, 422, 567 S.E.2d 231, 234 (2002) (holding the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act provides the exclusive remedy for employees who sustain a work-related injury).Â  
  Accordingly, the trial judge did not err in finding Hancock was Wal-Martâ€™s statutory 
  employee.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the trial judgeâ€™s 
  decision to grant Wal-Martâ€™s motion for summary judgment is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Betty P. O'Neal,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Intermedical Hospital of South Carolina,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3646
Heard March 12, 2003 - Filed June 2, 
  2003

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART 


  
    
      
Richard J. Morgan, Robyn K. Wietecha, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Laura Puccia Valtorta, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  


HUFF, J.:Â  In this wage payment dispute, 
  the trial court trebled the juryâ€™s $1,350 award of damages to plaintiff Betty 
  P. Oâ€™Neal and ordered defendant Intermedical Hospital of South Carolina (Intermedical) 
  to pay Oâ€™Neal $8,100 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, and reverse in 
  part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Oâ€™Neal became employed as a registered nurse for 
  Intermedical on September 21, 1998.Â  Oâ€™Neal understood that her base pay was 
  to be $18.36 per hour with â€œshift differentialâ€ pay of an additional $1.50 per 
  hour for night shifts beginning after 11 p.m., and an additional $5.00 per hour 
  for weekend shifts.Â  She further understood that she was required to work every 
  other weekend. Â 
At some point in her employment, Oâ€™Neal began complaining 
  to Teri Hooper, who was in charge of Intermedicalâ€™s payroll, that she was not 
  receiving the proper pay.Â  On March 31, 1999, Oâ€™Neal filed a claim against Intermedical 
  with the Department of Labor for approximately $681.61 in wages owed.Â  Specifically, 
  Oâ€™Neal asserted that between January 9, 1999 and March 20, 1999, Intermedical 
  improperly withheld wages for 28.18 regular hours at $18.36 per hour, shift 
  differential pay for 17 weekend hours at $5.00 per hour, and shift differential 
  pay for 52.82 night hours at $1.50 per hour.Â  
After an investigation, the South Carolina Department of 
  Labor determined Intermedical failed to comply with the provisions of South 
  Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-40(D) in that it failed to pay Oâ€™Neal $376.09 
  in wages in accordance with her regular pay schedule. 
  [1] Â  Nonetheless, the Department of Labor ultimately found that as of March 
  25, 1999, Oâ€™Neal had been paid all wages due to her and had in fact been overpaid 
  by $110.77.Â  In August of 1999, the Department of Labor assessed a $375.00 penalty 
  against the hospital for the late payment of wages.Â  
In April 1999, Virginia Herring, Intermedicalâ€™s nurse manager, 
  created, posted, and distributed copies of the nursesâ€™ working schedule for 
  April 11 through May 9, 1999.Â  Herring scheduled Oâ€™Neal to work a number of 
  shifts, including a shift beginning at 11:00 p.m. on Friday, April 23, 1999.Â  
  By letter dated April 13, 1999, Oâ€™Neal complained to Herring that her regular 
  working schedule of two eight hours shifts and two twelve hour shifts had been 
  changed to five eight hour shifts without prior notice.Â  Oâ€™Neal also complained 
  that in creating the schedule, Herring failed to consider a prior request for 
  vacation and also improperly â€œsplit [her] weekend againâ€ by scheduling her to 
  work on Friday, April 23.Â  
On April 14, Herring and Oâ€™Neal met to discuss the concerns 
  Oâ€™Neal expressed in her April 13 letter; however, Herring and Oâ€™Neal dispute 
  the content of the discussion.Â  According to Herring, the parties did not discuss 
  the 11:00 p.m. April 23 shift during their meeting and Herring did not say or 
  do anything during the discussion to give Oâ€™Neal the impression she would remove 
  her from the schedule for April 23.Â  Herring further stated she informed Oâ€™Neal 
  she could not guarantee the schedule Oâ€™Neal requested in her April 13 letter.Â  
  Oâ€™Neal, on the other hand, asserted, although she remained on the master schedule 
  for April 23, Herring removed her from Herringâ€™s personal copy of the schedule 
  and assured her she would â€œfixâ€ it.Â  
Oâ€™Neal told a number of her co-workers that, although her 
  name still appeared on the posted work schedule for the 11:00 shift on April 
  23, she would not be working that night because she had discussed the matter 
  with Herring and had arranged to have the night off.Â  Based on information the 
  other employees relayed to Herring about these comments, Herring approached 
  Oâ€™Neal on the morning of April 23 and informed her she was still on the schedule 
  and was expected to report to work that night.Â  Oâ€™Neal responded that she would 
  not report to work because Herring had already given her the night off and because 
  Friday was a weekend night.Â  According to Herring, she explained to Oâ€™Neal that 
  the hospitalâ€™s shift/differential pay policy did not apply to scheduling and 
  Saturday and Sunday were weekend days for scheduling purposes.Â  Oâ€™Neal argued 
  that Friday night shifts constituted weekend work according to the hospitalâ€™s 
  policy.Â  Herring reiterated that she expected Oâ€™Neal to report to work that 
  night and inquired whether Oâ€™Neal was refusing to do so.Â  Oâ€™Neal confirmed that 
  she would not report to work that night.Â  Herring again told Oâ€™Neal she expected 
  her to report to work that night.Â  Oâ€™Neal replied, â€œYou do what you gotta do 
  and Iâ€™ll do what I gotta do.â€Â  
Oâ€™Neal did not, in fact, work on April 23.Â  On April 28, 
  1999, Herring called Oâ€™Neal in for a conference, at which time she informed 
  Oâ€™Neal her employment with Intermedical was being terminated for insubordination, 
  refusal to work a scheduled shift, and unexcused absence from work.Â  
Oâ€™Neal instituted the instant action against Intermedical 
  on June 1, 1999, alleging (1) wrongful discharge in retaliation for filing a 
  claim with the Department of Labor;Â  (2) nonpayment of wages earned during the 
  employment relationship including weekend shift differentials, overtime work, 
  night hours, and regular hours;Â  (3) and nonpayment of 138.42 hours of accrued 
  time off pay due upon her discharge from employment.Â  Oâ€™Neal also sought an 
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Intermedical answered, denying Oâ€™Neal was 
  entitled to any of the relief requested in her complaint.Â  Intermedical also 
  affirmatively asserted that it acted at all times in good faith and that Oâ€™Nealâ€™s 
  own conduct caused all adverse employment action taken against her.Â  
Prior to trial, Intermedical sought and was granted leave 
  to amend its pleading to include, as an additional affirmative defense, the 
  assertion that Oâ€™Neal breached her duty of loyalty to the hospital. [2] Â  Intermedical also moved for summary judgment on Oâ€™Nealâ€™s claim 
  for wrongful discharge.Â  The trial court granted the motion and the trial proceeded 
  on the actions for (1) nonpayment of wages due during the employment relationship 
  and (2) nonpayment of wages due at the time of termination.Â  
At trial, Oâ€™Neal asserted the hospital shorted her 28.18 
  hours of regular pay at $18.36 an hour, 17 hours of weekend pay at $5.00 an 
  hour, and 52.82 hours of night pay at $1.50 an hour, for a total due of $681.61.Â  
  She also sought 138.42 hours of accrued time off at $18.36 an hour, for a total 
  of $2,541.39.Â  Intermedical took the position that although it failed to pay 
  Oâ€™Neal all of her wages in a timely manner, the hospital had, by the time of 
  her discharge, paid Oâ€™Neal all of the wages she was due during her employment 
  at the hospital, including shift differential pay.Â  Intermedical did not dispute 
  that Oâ€™Neal had accrued 138.42 hours of time off for which she was not paid 
  at the time of her discharge.Â  The hospital sought to establish, however, that 
  Oâ€™Neal was terminated for misconduct, in which case the hospitalâ€™s policy prohibits 
  payment for accrued time off.Â  In attempting to establish that Oâ€™Nealâ€™s misconduct 
  warranted her termination, Intermedical introduced evidence relating to her 
  failure to work her scheduled shift on April 23, 1999, as well as other incidents 
  such as â€œnodding offâ€ at work and being unfriendly to co-workers.Â  
At the close of evidence, Intermedical requested that the 
  trial court give the following charge to the jury (Defendantâ€™s Request to charge 
  No. 10):

It is not for you to judge the wisdom or reasonableness of 
  any of [Intermedicalâ€™s] business decisions.Â  You cannot require an employer 
  to use business practices or policies you prefer or like, nor is it your role 
  to second-guess or substitute your judgment for [Intermedicalâ€™s] judgment.Â  

Likewise, it was [Intermedicalâ€™s] prerogative and right, 
  not [Oâ€™Nealâ€™s], to establish relevant criteria and expectations regarding performance 
  for any work that [Oâ€™Neal] might have performed, if any, for [Intermedical].

The trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury did not include the 
  requested language; however, the court charged the jury as follows:

Among the fundamental duties of the employee is the obligation 
  to yield obedience to all reasonable rules, orders, and instructions of the 
  employer and willful or intentional disobedience as a general rule justifies 
  dismissal of the employee.
The employee is bound to obey all of the employerâ€™s lawful 
  and reasonable commands even though such commands may under the circumstances 
  seem harsh and severe, but the employer has a right to manage his own affairs 
  and to establish and enforce any lawful and reasonable policies and instructions 
  and it must be a very extreme case in which an employee would be justified in 
  refusing to obey those orders.

Intermedical objected to the trial courtâ€™s failure 
  to include the requested charge.Â  The trial court noted the exception, but declined 
  to recharge the jury, reasoning that the courtâ€™s original charge sufficiently 
  encompassed the requested language.Â  
The jury returned a $1,350 verdict in favor of 
  Oâ€™Neal for wages owed after discharge, but found in favor of Intermedical on 
  the action for wages due during the period of employment.Â  
After the jury returned its verdict, Oâ€™Neal 
  moved for attorneyâ€™s fees and treble damages.Â  By order dated March 9, 2001, 
  the trial court granted both motions, trebling the damage award to $4,050 and 
  ordering Intermedical to contribute $8,100 toward Oâ€™Nealâ€™s $9,112.50 attorneyâ€™s 
  fees bill.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Jury Charge
Intermedical asserts the trial court erred in failing to 
  instruct the jury in accordance with Defendantâ€™s Request to Charge No. 10. Specifically, 
  Intermedical argues the trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury did not adequately 
  instruct the jury as to its obligation to apply and enforce Intermedicalâ€™s policies 
  regardless of personal preferences or opinions, thereby creating the opportunity 
  for the jury to judge the hospitalâ€™s policy on nonpayment for accrued time off 
  to employees terminated for misconduct.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe trial judge is required to charge only the current and 
  correct law of South Carolina.â€Â  McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 
  306, 457 S.E.2d 603, 606 (1995).Â  Further, â€œ[r]efusal to give a properly requested 
  charge is not error if the general instructions are sufficiently broad to enable 
  the jury to understand the law and the issues involved.â€Â  Id.
Intermedical cites two federal cases involving 
  employment discrimination in support of its requested jury charge.Â  In Furnco 
  Constr. Corp. v. Waters, 438 U.S. 567, 578 (1978), the Supreme Court, in 
  discussing the Seventh Circuit Court of Appealsâ€™ decision regarding employer 
  hiring procedures, stated, â€œCourts are generally less competent than employers 
  to restructure business practices, and unless mandated to do so by Congress 
  they should not attempt it.â€Â  In Holder v. City of Raleigh, 867 F.2d 
  823, 828 (4th Cir.1989), the Court of Appeals, citing Furnco, 
  stated, â€œWe have no authority simply to require employers to use the â€˜bestâ€™ 
  standards and procedures available to them.â€Â  Neither of these cases embrace 
  the specific law as proposed in Intermedicalâ€™s request to charge.Â  Intermedical 
  cites no South Carolina law supporting such a charge.Â  
Further, even if we were to assume the proposed charge was 
  the correct and current law of South Carolina, we find no error.Â  Although the 
  trial court refused to instruct the jury in exact accordance with Intermedicalâ€™s 
  request to charge, the court explicitly instructed the jury that an employee 
  is â€œbound to obey all of the employerâ€™s lawful and reasonable commands even 
  though such commands may under the circumstances seem harsh and severe.â€Â  The 
  court further instructed the jury that â€œthe employer has a right to manage his 
  own affairs and to establish and enforce any lawful and reasonable policies 
  and instructions . . .â€Â  In our view, the courtâ€™s instructions to the jury sufficiently 
  conveyed the concepts that an employer has the right to establish and enforce 
  any lawful and reasonable business policies, and an employee is obligated to 
  obey the employer, even if an employerâ€™s commands or policies seem harsh or 
  severe.Â  Accordingly, we find the instructions were sufficiently broad to enable 
  the jury to understand the law and the issues involved.
II.Â  Treble Damages
Intermedical also argues the trial court erred in awarding 
  Oâ€™Neal treble damages.Â  We agree.
Section 41-10-80(C) of the South Carolina Wage Payment Act 
  provides in part:

In case of any failure to pay wages due to an employee as 
  required by Section 41-10-40 or 41-10-50 the employee may recover in a civil 
  action an amount equal to three times the full amount of the unpaid wages, plus 
  costs and reasonable attorney's fees as the court may allow.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-80(C) (Supp. 2002).Â Â  
In interpreting this section, our Supreme Court has held 
  that the statuteâ€™s explicit provision that the employee â€œmayâ€ recover treble 
  damages signifies permission, which generally means that the action spoken of 
  is optional or discretionary.Â  The court went on to state as follows:

Thus, by using â€œmayâ€, rather than â€œshallâ€, the legislature 
  has provided that the penalty is discretionary with the judge.Â  This interpretation 
  accords with the purpose of the Wage Payment Act, to wit:Â  to protect employees 
  from the unjustified and wilful retention of wages by the employer.Â  The 
  imposition of treble damages in those cases where there is a bona fide dispute 
  would be unjust and harsh.

Rice v. Multimedia, Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 98, 456 S.E.2d 
  381, 383 (1995) (emphasis added) (citations omitted). 
Subsequent to Rice, our Supreme Court considered the 
  wage withholding case of Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 
  335 S.C. 598, 518 S.E.2d 591 (1999).Â  Futch was employed by McAllister Towing 
  (Employer) as a tugboat captain and local manager of its operations in Georgetown.Â  
  After Employer informed Futch his job would terminate at the end of 1993, Futch, 
  who knew Employer considered ceasing operations in the area, began making plans 
  with a co-worker to start their own tugboat business.Â  After learning of Futchâ€™s 
  plans, Employer fired Futch and refused to pay him $4,200 in monthly commissions 
  Futch had earned.Â  Futch brought an action against Employer seeking $4,200, 
  as well as treble damages and attorneyâ€™s fees, under the Wage Payment Act.Â  
  The jury awarded Futch the full $4,200 sought, and the trial judge trebled the 
  damages and awarded Futch attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  On appeal, this court reversed, 
  holding the trial judge should have granted Employerâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  
  The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed this court, reinstating the 
  jury verdict.Â  The court, however, declined to reinstate the award of treble 
  damages and attorneyâ€™s fees finding there was a bona fide dispute about whether 
  Employer owed Futch any wages.Â  In support of its decision, the court cited 
  Rice for the proposition that the â€œimposition of treble damages in cases 
  where there is a bona fide dispute would be unjust and harsh, and [the] Legislature 
  did not intend to deter litigation of reasonable good faith wage disputes.â€Â  
  Futch, 335 S.C. at 612, 518 S.E.2d at 598.
In determining the imposition of treble damages was proper 
  in the instant case, the trial court reasoned:

The Court finds the issue of whether [Intermedical] acted 
  in good faith and terminated [Oâ€™Neal] for cause was submitted to the jury.Â  
  The jury determined that [Oâ€™Neal] was entitled to recover accrued time off and 
  awarded her a verdict.Â  The jury therefore determined [Intermedical] did not 
  terminate [Oâ€™Neal] for cause and thus no good faith basis for refusal to pay 
  benefits was established.Â  Accordingly, the Court hereby trebles the jury verdict 
  to $4,050.00.Â  

The juryâ€™s verdict in favor of Oâ€™Neal does not lend itself 
  to the interpretation espoused by the trial court.Â  As evidenced by the decisions 
  in Futch and Rice, a finding that an employee is entitled to recover 
  unpaid wages is not equivalent to a finding that there existed no bona fide 
  dispute as to the employeeâ€™s entitlement to those wages.Â  Further, Intermedical 
  did not dispute the number of time off hours Oâ€™Neal had accrued at the time 
  she was terminated.Â  Nonetheless, the jury awarded her damages equal to payment 
  for only a portion of those hours, indicating the jury determined that Intermedical 
  properly withheld payment for the remaining portion of accrued hours.Â  The juryâ€™s 
  finding in this regard belies the trial courtâ€™s determination that, based on 
  the award of damages, the jury necessarily determined that Intermedical failed 
  to establish a good faith basis for refusal to pay the wages at the time of 
  Oâ€™Nealâ€™s discharge from employment.Â  Therefore, to the extent the trial court 
  found the juryâ€™s verdict was equivalent to a finding that no bona fide dispute 
  existed, such finding was erroneous.
At any rate, our reading of the record convinces us a bona 
  fide dispute existed as to whether and to what extent Oâ€™Neal was entitled to 
  payment for accrued time off.Â  See The Father v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs., Op. No. 25603 (S.C. Sup.Ct. filed March 10, 2003) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 9 at 30-31) (holding, where the decision to impose sanctions is 
  to be decided by a judge and not a jury, it sounds in equity rather than law 
  such that the South Carolina Constitution mandates the appellate court take 
  its own view of the facts).Â  It is undisputed Intermedicalâ€™s policy was to refuse 
  payment for accrued time off to employees terminated for misconduct, and Oâ€™Neal 
  does not contest the validity of the policy itself.Â  The parties offered contradictory 
  testimony as to whether Herring ever agreed to remove Oâ€™Neal from the schedule 
  for April 23, 1999.Â  It is undisputed, however, that prior to the scheduled 
  shift, Herring made clear to Oâ€™Neal that she was expected to report to work 
  at the scheduled time and Oâ€™Neal made a conscious decision not to do so.Â  Further, 
  the parties expressed conflicting interpretations of the definition of â€œweekend 
  hoursâ€ for purposes of determining whether the terms and conditions of Oâ€™Nealâ€™s 
  employment obligated her to work on the disputed date.Â  Thus, we find there 
  existed at least a bona fide dispute as to whether Oâ€™Neal was terminated for 
  misconduct and, concomitantly, a bona fide disagreement as to whether she was 
  entitled to payment for accrued time off.Â  Again, the propriety of treble damages 
  under the Wage Payment Act turns not on whether an employer is successful in 
  defending against a suit for nonpayment of wages, but whether there existed 
  a bona fide dispute concerning payment of the wages.Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s award of treble damages is 
  reversed and the juryâ€™s original award of damages reinstated.Â  
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Finally, Intermedical asserts error in the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees to Oâ€™Neal.Â  It argues there was a good faith dispute as to 
  the wages due Oâ€™Neal and therefore Oâ€™Neal was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  Intermedical further argues, even if Oâ€™Neal was entitled to collect some attorneyâ€™s 
  fees, the lower court awarded her an excessive amount based on the various factors 
  for awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.
We agree with Intermedical that there was a bona fide dispute 
  as to whether Intermedical owed Oâ€™Neal any wages such that the imposition of 
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees was also improper pursuant to Futch v. McAllister 
  Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 518 S.E.2d 591 (1999) and Rice 
  v. Multimedia, Inc., 318 S.C. 95, 456 S.E.2d 381 (1995).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the trial court 
  is affirmed as to the jury charge, and reversed as to the award of treble damages 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
ANDERSON, J., and MOREHEAD, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-40(D) (Supp. 2002) provides:Â  â€œEvery 
    employer in the State shall pay all wages due at the time and place designated 
    as required by subsection (A) of Â§ 41-10-30.â€Â  Subsection (A) of Â§ 41-10-30 
    provides, inter alia, that â€œ[e]very employer shall notify each employee in 
    writing at the time of hiring . . . the time and place of payment. . . .â€Â  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-10-30 (Supp. 2002). 

 
   
    [2] Intermedical also sought leave to amend its pleadings to include breach 
    of duty of loyalty as a counterclaim.Â  The trial court declined to allow the 
    amendment for purposes of asserting a counterclaim.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Andre Tufts,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3647
Heard April 16, 2003 â€“ Filed June 2, 
  2003Â Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Andre D. Tufts appeals his 
  conviction for criminal sexual conduct in the third degree, asserting the trial 
  judge erred in admitting improper evidence of his character.Â  We affirm.
I.Â  FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Tufts was charged with CSC third as a result of 
  an incident that allegedly occurred at Aiken Region Medical Center, where Tufts 
  was employed as an orthopedic technician.Â  The victim injured her back and was 
  permanently disabled as a result of a fall in 1991.Â  In March of 1997, 
  she became incapacitated after performing exercises to build up her strength.Â  
  When she telephoned her physician, he requested that she go to the hospital.Â  
  The victim went to the Emergency Room at Aiken Regional Medical Center and was 
  seen by a doctor.Â  After the doctor examined the victim, a nurse gave her a 
  shot.Â  When the nurse came back to check on her, Tufts came with her.Â  
  Thereafter, the nurse left, and Tufts remained in the room.Â  According to the 
  victim, Tufts represented himself to be an orthopedic doctor and began to examine 
  her. Â While examining the victim, Tufts slipped his hands beneath her 
  panties and digitally penetrated her.Â  The victim told several nurses what had 
  happened and requested that they check Tuftsâ€™s hands for a â€œspecimen.â€Â  When 
  the victim returned to her home, she called the police.
The next day, Detective Dwayne Courtney requested 
  that Tufts come to the Aiken Public Safety Department for an interview.Â  During 
  the interview, Tufts denied the victimâ€™s allegations.Â  At the conclusion 
  of the interview, Tufts exited the public safety building.Â  However, he returned 
  to Courtneyâ€™s office a few minutes later and requested to talk to him again.Â  
  During that second interview, Tufts told Courtney that he had been arrested 
  and charged in a sexual matter in Augusta, Georgia in 1995 while he worked at 
  the University Hospital.Â  When Courtney told Tufts that it sounded like he may 
  have a problem, Tufts stated that he knew he had a problem with his sexual desires.Â  
  Tufts then requested that he be allowed to go home and discuss the matter 
  with his girlfriend.Â  When Courtney ran a check on Tufts the next day, he discovered 
  he had been charged in a similar incident in Georgia that had been nolle 
  prossed.Â  
At trial, the State sought to introduce Courtneyâ€™s 
  testimony regarding the two conversations he had had with Tufts. [1] Â  Following in camera testimony from both Courtney and 
  Tufts, the trial judge found that the second statement had been voluntarily 
  made.Â  After an extensive colloquy with counsel, the trial judge ruled that 
  the alleged statement concerning the prior charge in Georgia was inadmissible. 
  Â However, he found that the portion of the conversation concerning Tuftsâ€™s 
  knowledge that he had a problem with his sexual desires could be construed as 
  a confession and was therefore admissible.Â  Immediately after this ruling, 
  Detective Courtney testified before the jury.Â  His testimony regarding Tuftsâ€™s 
  second statement to him was as follows:
Well, Mr. Tufts put his hands 
  into his pockets.Â  He was standing up, and I was standing near my desk.Â  He 
  put both hands into his pockets and started to sway from side to side, and hung 
  his head down.Â  At that time, he said, that he knew he had a problem with his 
  sexual desires, but that he wanted to go home and talk with his girlfriend that 
  night, and after he talked to his girlfriend, he would come back to see me on 
  the next day, which would have been Friday, and tell me what really happened 
  to [the victim] in the emergency room.Â  
The jury convicted Tufts of CSC third, and the 
  trial judge sentenced him to six years.Â  This appeal follows.
II.Â  DISCUSSION
Tufts contends Detective Courtneyâ€™s testimony constituted 
  improper character evidence against him.Â  In support of his argument, Tufts 
  relies primarily on State v. Nelson, 331 S.C. 1, 501 S.E.2d 716 (1998).Â  
  In Nelson, the supreme court reversed this courtâ€™s decision to affirm 
  Nelsonâ€™s conviction.Â  Nelson, who was convicted at trial of four counts of first 
  degree CSC with a minor and four counts of lewd act on a child, made post-arrest 
  statements to police that he was uncomfortable around adult women and that he 
  had fantasies about children.Â  At trial, the judge overruled Nelsonâ€™s objection 
  to testimony concerning his fantasies or likes or dislikes of females.Â  The 
  South Carolina Supreme Court reversed, holding that Nelsonâ€™s general sexual 
  attitudes were not relevant or material to the crime charged because they were 
  admitted to show character.Â  Id. at 16, 501 S.E.2d at 724.
The State argues initially that this issue is not 
  preserved for appellate review because the trial judgeâ€™s in camera ruling 
  was not a final ruling, citing State v. Shumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 
  859 (1993).Â  Shumpert involved an objection to testimony lodged at an 
  in limine ruling that was not repeated when the offending testimony was 
  actually offered.Â Â  It is well settled that a ruling on an in limine 
  motion is usually not final and the losing party must renew his or her objection 
  when the evidence is presented.Â  Id.; State v. Gagum, 328 S.C. 
  105, 495 S.E.2d 231 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, where the motion is ruled on 
  immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question, no further 
  objection is necessary.Â  Samples v. Mitchell, 329 S.C. 105, 495 S.E.2d 
  231 (Ct. App. 1998); State v. Mueller, 319 S.C. 266, 460 S.E.2d 409 (Ct. 
  App. 1995).Â  Here, it is clear that the trial judgeâ€™s decision, reached after 
  in camera testimony, lengthy discussion with counsel, and an overnight 
  recess, was a final ruling.Â  Moreover, immediately after the trial judge ruled, 
  the State called Detective Courtney to the stand, and he testified in front 
  of the jury.Â  Because there was no opportunity for the trial judge to change 
  his ruling, we find that Tuftsâ€™s objections prior to the ruling preserved the 
  issue for appellate review.
On the merits, we find the statement was properly 
  admitted.Â  Although the trial judge disallowed most of the statements allegedly 
  made by Tufts in his second interview with Courtney, he did permit Courtney 
  to testify that Tufts told him he had a problem with his sexual desires.Â  This 
  statement is similar to the type of evidence presented in Nelson, which 
  the supreme court disallowed. There the court stated:Â  â€œGenerally, only those 
  parts of a confession or statement made to police which are relevant and material 
  to the crime charged should be received into evidence . . . .Â  [W]e find [Nelsonâ€™s] 
  general sexual attitudes were not relevant or material to the crime charged 
  because they were admitted to show character.â€Â  Nelson, 331 S.C. at 15-16, 
  501 S.E.2d at 723-24.Â  
We believe the circumstances of this case are distinguishable 
  from Nelson.Â  In Nelson, the State sought to admit a number of 
  toys, tapes of childrenâ€™s shows, storybooks, and photographs of young children.Â  
  Initially, the trial judge thought the offer of evidence was ludicrous.Â  However, 
  after the Stateâ€™s expert on sexual trauma testified that pedophiles often maintain 
  a large stash of childlike items, the trial judge admitted the evidence.Â  Over 
  the defendantâ€™s objection, the trial judge ruled the evidence was probative 
  â€œnot of a â€˜character issueâ€™ but of a â€˜personality characteristic,â€™â€ i.e., that 
  the defendant was a pedophile.Â  Id. at 5, 501 S.E.2d at 718.Â  
In addition, the State admitted statements made 
  by the defendant to the police.Â  The defendant stated that he was uncomfortable 
  around adult women and that he had fantasies about children.Â  The supreme court 
  held that the defendantâ€™s general sexual attitudes were admitted only to show 
  character.Â  In rejecting the evidence and the defendantâ€™s statements, the court 
  stated: â€œâ€˜A necessary corollary to the presumption of innocence is that a defendant 
  must be tried for what he did, not for who he is.â€™â€Â  Id. at 15, 501 S.E.2d 
  723 (quoting State v. Melcher, 678 A.2d 146, 151 (1996)). 
In Nelson, the offered evidence and the 
  defendantâ€™s statements were relevant only to prove that the defendant was a 
  pedophile.Â  The fact that the defendant was a pedophile spoke only to his propensity 
  to commit the charged offense, and evidence thereof was thus inadmissible.Â  
  In the present case, however, Tuftsâ€™s statements were not admitted to show his 
  character; instead, they were admitted as a confession to the specific crime 
  charged.Â  
The trial judge gave much consideration to the 
  arguments of counsel and ultimately ruled the statement was admissible because 
  he believed the jury could view Tuftsâ€™s statement as a confession.Â  The trial 
  judge found that Tuftsâ€™s comment regarding his sexual desires was sufficiently 
  related to the officerâ€™s questioning about the specific crime to support the 
  inference that Tufts simply chose to convey his confession in that manner.Â  
  The trial judge believed this fact distinguished the statement from mere character 
  evidence.Â  As an illustration, the trial judge stated, â€œSo in this context or 
  if someone were to say, well I realize that Iâ€™m a murderer and I shouldnâ€™t have 
  done it.Â  Thatâ€™s an admission of murder rather than a statement that I have 
  a bad character, in this situation.â€Â  The trial judge further stated, â€œIt is 
  his way of explaining or justifying to the officer what he is admitting to having 
  done . . . .â€Â  Furthermore, Tuftsâ€™s final statement, that he would 
  return the next morning to explain what really happened to the victim, definitively 
  links his statement to the specific crime charged. 
We agree with the trial judge that Tuftsâ€™s statement 
  was not introduced to show his bad character; rather, we believe his statement 
  was intended to convey to the officer that he had committed the sexual assault 
  on the victim and that he would return the next morning to give the complete 
  details of the incident.Â  Certainly, there are many ways in which a suspect 
  may choose to implicate himself in a crime.Â  When asked of his guilt, he might 
  simply nod affirmatively, or he might offer a complete recounting of the entire 
  crime.Â  Here, Tufts returned of his own free will to Courtneyâ€™s office and voluntarily 
  offered his statement that he knew he had a problem and that he would return 
  the next day to describe what really happened to the victim.Â  In our view, this 
  statement was properly admissible as a confession to the charged crime.
For the foregoing reasons, Tuftsâ€™s 
  conviction is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
CURETON and GOOLSBY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Tufts did not dispute the first conversation but denied that the 
    second conversation had ever taken place.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Frances Walsh as Personal Representative of the Estate of Jerome Walsh, 
        Deceased, and in her individual capacity,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joyce K. Woods, f/k/a Joyce K. Walsh,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

REVERSED AND REMANDED

Opinion No. 3648
Heard March 11, 2003 â€“ Filed June 2, 
  2003


  
    
      
Russell H. Putnam, Jr., of Hinesville; for Appellant
John S. Nichols, of Columbia; Kelli Lister Sullivan, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, J.:Â  Frances Dudley Walsh (Frances), 
  individually and in her capacity as personal representative of the estate of 
  her deceased husband, Jerome J. Walsh (Walsh), brought this action against Walshâ€™s 
  former wife, Joyce K. Woods (Joyce). In her complaint, Frances seeks relief 
  pertaining to the disposition of surviving spouse benefits made available through 
  Walshâ€™s retirement plan.Â  Frances appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order granting 
  Joyceâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
Walsh married his first wife, Joyce, 
  in 1957, and the two separated in 1970. Although they continued to live apart, 
  Walsh and Joyce remained married for twenty years after their separation. Â In 
  1989, Walsh retired from E.I. Du Pont De Numours And Company (DuPont) after 
  approximately forty years of employment.Â  During his tenure at DuPont, Walsh 
  participated in a DuPont sponsored pension benefits plan governed by the Employee 
  Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, 29 U.S.C. 1001 et. seq. 
  (â€œERISAâ€). Contemporaneously with his retirement, Walsh signed a Post Retirement 
  Company-Paid Survivor Benefits and Spouse Benefit Option designating Joyce, 
  to whom he was still married, as the sole beneficiary of his surviving spouse 
  benefits plan in the event he predeceased her. Walshâ€™s monthly benefit was therefore 
  reduced by the amount necessary to cover the cost of the survivor benefit plan.Â  

Walsh and Joyce were divorced by order 
  of the family court dated August 24, 1990. Â Incident to the divorce, 
  Walsh and Joyce entered into an agreement which the family court approved, adopted, 
  and incorporated into the divorce decree.Â  The decree provided, in relevant 
  part:

[T]he parties shall sign whatever documents or other paperwork 
  that is necessary to enforce this Agreement.Â  I find that the parties have further 
  agreed that each shall retain what .Â  .Â  . retirement plans, pension plans .Â  
  .Â  . etc., that he or she has in his or her possession.Â  If the wife is required 
  to sign any papers concerning the husbandâ€™s retirement or benefit options from 
  DuPont of Westinghouse, then she shall sign those. 

It is undisputed Walsh 
  never presented Joyce with any documents to sign regarding his retirement benefits, 
  and that neither party attempted to obtain a Qualified Domestic Relations Order 
  (QDRO) reassigning the surviving spouse benefits during Walshâ€™s lifetime.
On May 31, 1991, Walsh advised DuPont 
  he was divorced from Joyce and desired to change the beneficiary of his pension 
  plan to his wife Frances and requested the paperwork to accomplish this 
  [1] .Â  In 1994, Walsh married Frances, with whom he had been involved since 
  1980. On November 30, 1994, Walsh wrote to DuPont again advising the 
  company that he was married to Frances and wished to designate her asÂ  beneficiary 
  under his retirement plan, and that the company should send him any documentation 
  necessary to effectuate the change in beneficiary.Â  Despite the May 31, 1991 
  letter and other subsequent communications with DuPont wherein Walsh referred 
  to Frances as his designated beneficiary, the change Walsh requested 
  was never made legally effective.Â  
Walsh died testate on January 27, 1996. Pursuant 
  to the terms of Walshâ€™s will, Frances became the sole beneficiary and the Personal 
  Representative of his estate.Â  
In 1997, Frances instituted an 
  action against DuPont, which was removed to federal court, seeking a judicial 
  finding that Walshâ€™s surviving spouse benefits should be paid to her and not 
  Joyce.Â  DuPont moved for and was granted summary judgment on the grounds that 
  no QDRO existed terminating Joyceâ€™s right to receive the benefits at the time 
  of Walshâ€™s retirement. 
Thereafter, Frances contacted John W. 
  Harte, the attorney who represented Walsh in his divorce from Joyce, and requested 
  that he prepare and submit a QDRO to DuPont.Â  Harte prepared the QDRO, then 
  contacted Vickie Johnson, the attorney who represented Joyce in the divorce 
  action, and requested that she obtain Joyceâ€™s signature on the document. Joyce 
  did not sign the QDRO but authorized Johnson to sign it on her behalf.Â  Joyce 
  noted on the document, however, that she authorized her signature under protest 
  and out of concern she would be held in contempt of court if she refused to 
  sign.Â  
In August of 1998, Harte submitted the 
  QDRO to DuPont.Â  In a letter dated September 16, 1998, DuPont advised Harte 
  that the document was unenforceable as a QDRO inasmuch as â€œ[a] QDRO cannot be 
  entered after the death of the participant. A participant must be a living person.Â  
  There was no QDRO in effect at the participantâ€™s death that awarded any benefits 
  to an alternate payee.Â  Therefore, there are no benefits payable pursuant to 
  a QDRO.â€ In addition, the letter from DuPont advised that even if the document 
  had been prepared at some point prior to Walshâ€™s death, it would nonetheless 
  be ineffective to divest Joyce of her surviving spouse benefits inasmuch as 
  ERISA requires that married participants be offered qualified joint and survivor 
  annuities and their spouses must be offered the option to accept or waive the 
  benefit.Â Â  Once this election is made it is irrevocable. 
Frances filed the instant action against 
  Joyce on December 18, 2000, seeking recovery under seven theories of relief: 
  1) unjust enrichment; 2) â€œlaw of the caseâ€; 3) res judicata; 4) collateral estoppel; 
  5) breach of contract; 6) bad faith breach of contract; and 7) conversion. Joyce 
  answered, denying Frances was entitled to the relief sought in her complaint, 
  and asserted as defenses: 1) expiration of the statute of limitations; 2) failure 
  to state a claim upon which relief can be granted; 3) laches; and 4) res
judicata. 

The parties filed cross motions for summary 
  judgment.Â  Joyce argued, inter alia, that all of Francesâ€™s causes 
  of actions failed because the surviving spouse benefits vested in Joyce in 1989, 
  at the time of Walshâ€™s retirement, and she could not now be divested of her 
  right to the benefits.Â Â  Joyce further asserted the applicable statute of limitations 
  bars the claims.Â  In support of her cross motion, Frances asserted generally 
  that no genuine issues of material fact existed and specifically that Joyce 
  had waived her rights to the benefits in the divorce decree.Â  In addition, Frances 
  asserted that the court could enforce the property settlement agreement by requiring 
  Joyce to disgorge herself of all surviving spouse benefit payments she had received 
  in the past and will receive in the future by transferring the payments to Frances.
By order dated January 28, 2001, the trial 
  court granted Joyceâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Specifically, the court 
  cited Hopkins v. AT&T, 105 F.3d 153, 157 (4th Cir. 1997), for the 
  propositions that 1) surviving spouse benefits vest in a plan participantâ€™s 
  current spouse on the date the participant retires, whether or not spouses are 
  married at the time the participant dies, and 2) surviving spouse benefits may 
  not be paid to a spouse who marries a participant after the participantâ€™s retirement.Â Â  
  The trial court expressly determined the holding in Hopkins was determinative 
  of the entire case and, therefore, declined to address Joyceâ€™s other grounds 
  for summary judgment and further declined to reach Francesâ€™s cross motion for 
  summary judgment.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.    Error Preservation
We turn our attention first to Joyceâ€™s 
  assertion Frances failed to properly preserve the issue of whether the trial 
  court properly found that all of Francesâ€™s claims were barred by ERISA provisions 
  inasmuch as the court expressly declined to rule on the issues and Frances did 
  not request, by a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion or otherwise, that the court address 
  such claims.Â  We hold the trial courtâ€™s express finding that it was â€œunnecessary 
  to reach Francesâ€™s cross motion for summary judgmentâ€ rendered Francesâ€™s remaining 
  issues moot and/or amounted to an effective denial of the cross motion.Â  As 
  such, any motion under Rule 59(e) requesting a specific ruling on the cross 
  motion for summary judgment would have been futile, and was in any event, not 
  necessary to discern the trial courtâ€™s decision as to the issues.Â  Under such 
  circumstances, a litigant is not required to move for relief pursuant to Rule 
  59(e) in order to properly preserve issues for review before this court.Â  See 
  Wilder Corp v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 77, 497 S.E.2d 731, 734 (1998) (noting 
  that proper use of 59(e) motion is to preserve issues raised to but not ruled 
  upon by the trial court); State v. Pace, 316 S.C. 71, 74, 447 S.E.2d 
  186, 187 (1994) (excusing the failure to make a contemporaneous objection where 
  the judge's comments are such that any objection would be futile); Jean Hoefer 
  Toal et. al. Appellate Practice in South Carolina 65-68 (1999).
  II.    Summary Judgment 
Frances argues the trial court erred in granting 
  Joyce summary judgment based on the courtâ€™s reasoning that ERISA provisions 
  governing vesting and non-alienability of surviving spouse benefit rights are 
  controlling as to the disposition of all of Francesâ€™s legal and equitable claims.Â Â  
  We agree.
Summary judgment is appropriate only when 
  it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact and the conclusions and 
  inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed. Garvin v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 
  343 S.C. 625, 628, 541 S.E.2d 831, 833 (2001).Â  Summary judgment is inappropriate, 
  however, where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify 
  the application of the law.Â  Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 484, 
  523 S.E.2d 795, 799 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In determining whether any triable issue 
  of fact exists so as to preclude summary judgment, the evidence and all inferences 
  reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the 
  nonmoving party.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 
  S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â    
Here, the trial court determined that ERISA provisions, 
  as interpreted and applied by a single Fourth Circuit case, were determinative 
  of every issue involved in this case.Â  Specifically, citing and relying exclusively 
  upon the holding in Hopkins, the trial court concluded that Frances could 
  not recover on any of her claims because the surviving spouse benefits vested 
  in Joyce on the date Walsh retired, and, further, the benefits could not be 
  paid to Frances because she married Walsh after the date of his retirement. 

In arriving at its ruling, the trial court failed to specifically 
  explore the applicability of federal case and statutory law pertaining to the 
  more narrowly drawn issue of whether the former spouse of an ERISA plan participant 
  may, incident to a separation agreement and in exchange for a comparable waiver 
  on the part of the other spouse, voluntarily waive his or her interest in vested 
  ERISA benefits.Â  In Estate of Altobelli v. Intâ€™l Bus. Machs. Corp., 77 
  F.3d 78 (4th Cir. 1996), a divorced spouse, who was designated beneficiary under 
  her ex-husbandâ€™s ERISA plan, waived her benefits through a marital settlement 
  agreement that was incorporated into a divorce decree.Â  The court found that 
  ERISAâ€™s anti-alienation clause did not apply to a voluntary waiver by a beneficiary, 
  since the purpose of the anti-alienation clause is to safeguard a stream of 
  income for the pensioner and his beneficiaries, and to bar a waiver in favor 
  of pensioner himself would not advance such a purpose.Â  The court held that 
  it was clear that each party intended to relinquish all interests in the otherâ€™s 
  pension plan and therefore the former wifeâ€™s waiver was to be given full effect.Â  
  Under the holding in Altobelli, we find it was error for the trial court 
  not to examine the language of the settlement agreement, which was incorporated 
  into the divorce decree, in order to determine if there was a clear intent by 
  Joyce to relinquish all of her interests in Walshâ€™s retirement plan and any 
  benefits emanating therefrom.
Further, we are compelled to agree with 
  Frances that although Joyce may have established an unassailable right to receive 
  the surviving spouse benefit payments directly from DuPont, Francesâ€™s claim 
  to the benefits are not, as found by the trial court, necessarily rendered untenable.Â  
  By way of example, neither the anti-alienation provisions of ERISA nor the courtâ€™s 
  holding in Hopkins are in any way determinative of whether Joyceâ€™s retention 
  of those benefits would constitute unjust enrichment in light of a voluntary 
  agreement to waive her rights to the benefits.Â  The mere fact that Joyce, and 
  not Frances, is entitled to receive surviving spouse benefit payments from DuPont 
  does not negate Francesâ€™s right to establish, under some legal or equitable 
  theory of recovery, that Joyce is not entitled to retain the payments.Â  See 
  Succession of Netterville, 579 So.2d 1046 (La. Ct. App. 1991) (Although 
  the surviving spouse should be recognized as the beneficiary of the pension 
  plans, she was made accountable to the first wife and heirs, who under Louisiana 
  law had certain vested rights under the stateâ€™s community property laws.)Â  
We find the issue of whether a former spouseâ€™s 
  right to retain benefits under her ex-husbandâ€™s ERISA plan may be voluntarily 
  relinquished is a question of first impression in South Carolina.Â  Important 
  questions of novel impression should not be decided on summary judgment if further 
  inquiry into the facts is necessary to clarify the application of the law. ML-Lee 
  Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 320 S.C. 143, 153, 463 
  S.E.2d 618, 624 (1997), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 327 S.C. 238, 
  489 S.E.2d 470 (1997).Â  As such, the grant of summary judgment was improper.Â  
  The case is remanded for further proceedings in accordance with this opinion.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â Â  
STILWELL J., concurs.Â  HOWARD, J., concurs in 
  part and dissents in part in a separate opinion.Â  
  HOWARD, J. (concurring in part and dissenting 
  in part):Â  Although I agree with my brethren that the issues raised in this 
  case are preserved for appeal, I do not agree the circuit court erred in granting 
  summary judgment. 
The pertinent facts may be succinctly 
  stated as follows.Â  Jerome Walsh married his first wife in 1957.Â  He worked 
  for E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company (â€œDupontâ€) for forty years, contributing 
  to a pension benefits plan controlled by the Employee Retirement Income Security 
  Act of 1974, 29 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1001-1461 (2003) (â€œERISAâ€).Â  He retired in 1989, while 
  still married to his first wife.Â  
Walsh and his first wife divorced in 1990, entering 
  into an agreement incorporated into the final decree, which stated as follows:

[T]he parties shall sign whatever documents or other paperwork 
  that is necessary to enforce this Agreement.Â  I find that the parties have further 
  agreed that each shall retain what . . . retirement plans, pension plans . . 
  . etc., that he or she has in his or her possession.Â  If the wife is required 
  to sign any papers concerning the husbandâ€™s retirement or benefit options from 
  Dupont of Westinghouse, then she shall sign those.Â  

Walsh married his second wife in 1994 
  and died in 1996.Â  No changes were made to the spousal survivor benefits in 
  his pension plan.Â  After the second wife was notified the first wife was the 
  beneficiary of the spousal retirement benefits, the second wife unsuccessfully 
  tried to block payment to the first wife by bringing an action in federal court.Â  
  However, having no Qualified Domestic Relations Order (â€œQDROâ€) to support her 
  position, she was unsuccessful.Â  She then brought this action, asserting the 
  following legal theories for recovery: (1) unjust enrichment; (2) breach of 
  contract; (3) conversion; and (4) bad faith breach of contract. [2] 
Citing Hopkins v. AT&T, 105 F.3d 153 
  (4th Cir. 1997), the circuit court granted summary judgment to the first wife, 
  concluding under any view of the facts she was vested with the survivor spouse 
  benefits before the divorce, and they were not affected by the decree or any 
  other event occurring thereafter.Â  After careful consideration of the pertinent 
  facts, I agree with this disposition of the case. 
In Hopkins, the husband retired after marrying 
  his second wife.Â  He then attempted to transfer spousal benefits to his first 
  wife in a QDRO to satisfy his overdue alimony obligations.Â  The court ruled 
  the Domestic Relations Order was not qualified, and was ineffective.Â  Writing 
  for the court, Judge Karen Williams noted the spousal benefits vested in the 
  second wife when the husband retired.Â  From that point on, those future benefits 
  were a separate, beneficial interest belonging to the second spouse as a beneficiary.Â  
  Under ERISA, a Domestic Relations Order is only â€œQualifiedâ€ if it assigns a 
  â€œbenefit payable with respect to a participant.â€Â  Because the order attempted 
  to assign a vested beneficiary interest and not a benefit payable with respect 
  to a participant, the court concluded the order was not â€œQualified.â€Â  Id. 
  at 157.
Hopkins stands as clear authority for the 
  proposition that the survivor spouse benefit vests in the spouse at the time 
  of the participantâ€™s retirement.Â  In this case, Walsh retired while still married 
  to his first wife.Â  Therefore, the survivor spouse benefit vested in the first 
  wife at that time, and it was her property.Â  
As the majority points out, ERISA does not preclude 
  the nonparticipating beneficiary from waiving the surviving spouse benefit through 
  specific language in a divorce settlement before the participantâ€™s retirement. 
  See Altobelli v. I.B.M., 77 F.3d 78, 81 (4th Cir. 1996) (Wilkinson, 
  J., dissenting); Fox Valley & Vicinity Constr. Workers Pension Fund v. 
  Brown, 897 F.2d 275, 280-281 (7th Cir. 1990) (en banc), cert. denied, 
  498 U.S. 820 (1990).Â  For example, in Altobelli, the wife executed a 
  Voluntary Separation and Property Settlement Agreement, incorporated into a 
  divorce decree, which stated:

All of the following property is hereafter the sole and exclusive 
  property of the Husband, and the wife hereby waives and transfers to the 
  Husband any interest that she may have in the property . . .
(g) Husbandâ€™s IBM pension and other deferred compensation 
  plans, if any.

77 F.3d at 80.
However, in this case, no such language appears 
  in any agreement between Walsh and his first wife.Â  The only language is that 
  previously noted in the divorce decree.Â  This language states only that each 
  party â€œretains what retirement plans, pension plans . . . etc., that 
  he or she has in his or her possession . . . .â€Â  Unlike Altobelli, Walsh 
  had retired at the point this agreement was entered.Â  Thus, the beneficial interest 
  had vested in the first wife, and she was in possession of it.Â  Furthermore, 
  the language does not contain a transfer, assignment, or waiver of any interest 
  in the retirement plan.Â  Taking the evidence in a light most favorable to the 
  second wife, the decree of divorce does not contain specific language waiving 
  the surviving spouseâ€™s interest.
The post-death attempt to modify the circumstances 
  through a family court order purporting to be a nunc pro tunc QDRO has 
  no efficacy for two reasons.Â  First, describing the action as nunc pro tunc 
  does not make it so.Â  Our supreme court has noted, a nunc pro tunc order 
  can be used only for the purpose of placing in the record evidence of judicial 
  action that has actually been taken, not to correct an error, or supply an omission, 
  of judicial action. See Ex Parte Strom, 343 S.C. 
  257, 265, 539 S.E.2d 699, 703 (2000). Second, the nonparticipating beneficial 
  interest had vested in the first wife at retirement.Â  Therefore, the order did 
  not relate to a benefit payable with respect to a participant. See Hopkins, 
  105 F.3d at 156.Â  Thus, it was not qualified.Â  Consequently, I would affirm 
  the trial court.

 
   [1]  Apparently, Walsh thought he had a common law 
    marriage with Frances.

 
   
    [2]  The complaint delineates â€œlaw of the caseâ€; â€œres judicataâ€; â€œcollateral 
    estoppelâ€; and â€œbad faithâ€ as additional causes of action.Â  Assuming, without 
    deciding, they represent separate causes of action, these issues fail for 
    the same reasons discussed below.
