title: State v. Baum
description: In this criminal matter, the appellant appeals his conviction for the murder of his stepfather following a second trial, after the first trial ended in a mistrial upon motion by the State.  He contends the discovery of the victim's body after the jury was sworn in the first trial did not constitute manifest necessity to justify a mistrial, and therefore a second trial was barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause.
text:
THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Uuno Mattias Baum, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Pickens County
Â Henry 
  F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3653
Submitted 
  April 7, 2003 â€“ Filed June 16, 2003

AFFIRMED


Deputy 
  Chief Attorney of S. C. Office of Appellate Defense Joseph L. Savitz, III , 
  of Columbia; for Appellant.
Attorney General 
  Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant 
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka; Assistant Attorney General Melody 
  J. Brown; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Edward G. McDonnel, of Columbia; 
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville; for Respondent.


HUFF, 
  J.:Â  Uuno Mattias â€œMattâ€ Baum was convicted of the murder of his stepfather, 
  Randall Pinion, and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Baum appeals his conviction 
  contending that his prosecution was barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause of 
  the United States and South Carolina Constitutions.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 
  26, 1999, Randall Pinion went to his bank and filled out an affidavit of forgery 
  concerning two checks in the amount of $450.00 apiece and made out to Matt Baum.Â  
  The bank employee who assisted Pinion gave him the original affidavit of forgery 
  and instructed him to take it to the police if he desired to prosecute.Â  On 
  October 27, 1999, two days prior to Pinionâ€™s disappearance, he arrived at work 
  upset and told a co-worker that Matt Baum, Pinionâ€™s stepson, had stolen some 
  money from him.Â  Pinion told the co-worker he would give Baum two days to repay 
  the money or he was going to turn Baum in to the police.Â  On the morning of 
  his disappearance, Pinion stated to the co-worker that he was giving Baum until 
  that evening to give him his money.Â  Pinion never filed a police report in regard 
  to the alleged forgeries.Â  Two weeks earlier, Baum threatened to kill Pinion 
  after Pinion had physically abused Baumâ€™s mother.Â  
On Friday, 
  October 29, 1999, Pinion disappeared after leaving work.Â  His black pickup truck 
  was not at his home on Friday night or Saturday morning, but appeared at his 
  house between 3:00 and 11:00 p.m. on Saturday, October 30.Â  Between 4:00 and 
  7:00 p.m. on Sunday October 31, the truck again disappeared from the house.Â  
  Pinionâ€™s truck was subsequently found in a church parking lot a few days later.Â  
  
On November 
  1, 1999, Baum sold a set of Taylor Made golf clubs to a sporting goods store, 
  explaining they belonged to his stepfather, who had passed away and left him 
  the clubs.Â  Pinion owned several sets of golf clubs, including a Taylor Made 
  set.Â  
Police 
  investigated Pinionâ€™s home and pickup truck and found Pinionâ€™s blood in various 
  places throughout his home, as well as in the bed of his pickup truck.Â  The 
  police also found a bloody shoe print inside Pinionâ€™s home.Â  The police concluded 
  that Pinion had been beaten to death inside of his home and someone thereafter 
  attempted to clean up the crime scene.Â  
Based on their investigation, the authorities developed Baum as a suspect in 
  Pinionâ€™s disappearance.Â  On November 7, 1999, after receiving a tip on his possible 
  location, police attempted to apprehend Baum as he fled in a white pickup truck.Â  
  The chase reached speeds of more than 100 miles per hour, and ended when the 
  white truck became disabled following a traffic accident.Â  When the police searched 
  the disabled truck they discovered the keys to Pinionâ€™s truck, a couple of Pinionâ€™s 
  checks, Baumâ€™s driverâ€™s license, and a pair of tennis shoes whose tread was 
  consistent with the bloody shoe print found inside Pinionâ€™s home.Â  
On November 11, 1999, the grand jury returned a true bill against Baum for Pinionâ€™s 
  murder, even though the police had not found Pinionâ€™s body.Â  Baumâ€™s trial began 
  on October 9, 2000, and the jury was sworn on that day.Â  After Court recessed 
  for the evening, the Easley Police Department was notified of the discovery 
  of an unidentified, decomposed body found on October 7, 2000 in McDowell County, 
  North Carolina.Â  The following day, the solicitor informed defense counsel and 
  the court that the State had evidence it was, in fact, the body of Randall Pinion.Â  
  The State moved for a mistrial or a continuance based upon the discovery of 
  Pinionâ€™s body.Â  Baumâ€™s counsel did not agree with the State and asserted they 
  were ready to proceed to trial.Â  
The circuit court granted the Stateâ€™s motion for a mistrial finding it was imperative 
  the jury charged with deciding the case be given all relevant evidence upon 
  which to base its decision.Â  The court concluded there was a possibility that 
  exculpatory evidence would be revealed and that the discovery of Pinionâ€™s body 
  constituted manifest necessity to grant a mistrial.Â  Baumâ€™s second trial began 
  on January 22, 2001, at which time Baum objected to the new trial and moved 
  the State be barred from proceeding to trial on the ground that it violated 
  the Double Jeopardy Clause.Â  The circuit court denied Baumâ€™s motion and Baum 
  was subsequently convicted for Pinionâ€™s murder.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Baum 
  argues the circuit court erred when it allowed the second trial to proceed because 
  the discovery of Pinionâ€™s body did not constitute manifest necessity to justify 
  a mistrial, and therefore, the second trial was barred by the Double Jeopardy 
  Clause.Â  We disagree.
The Double Jeopardy Clauses of the United States and South Carolina Constitutions 
  prevent all citizens from being placed twice in jeopardy of life and liberty.Â  
  See U.S. Const. amend. V (â€œNo person shall be . . . subject for the same 
  offence to be twice put in jeopardy of life or limb . . . â€); S.C. Const. art. 
  I, Â§ 12 (â€œNo person shall be subject for the same offense to be twice put in 
  jeopardy of life or liberty . . . â€).Â  The Fifth Amendment of the United States 
  Constitution is made applicable to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment 
  due process clause.Â  See Benton v. Maryland, 395 U.S. 784, 794 
  (1969) (â€œ[T]he double jeopardy prohibition of the Fifth Amendment represents 
  a fundamental ideal in our constitutional heritage, and . . . should apply to 
  the States through the Fourteenth Amendmentâ€).Â  Pursuant to the Double Jeopardy 
  Clause, a defendant is protected from (1) prosecution for the same offense after 
  acquittal, (2) prosecution for the same offense after conviction, and (3) multiple 
  prosecution for the same offense after an improvidently granted mistrial.Â  State 
  v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 27-28, 236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977).Â  
Generally, jeopardy attaches when the jury is sworn and impaneled, unless the 
  defendant consents to the juryâ€™s discharge before it reaches a verdict or legal 
  necessity mandates the juryâ€™s discharge.Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 
  454, 457, 539 S.E.2d 717, 718 (Ct. App. 2000).

Unlike 
  the situation in which the trial has ended in an acquittal or conviction, retrial 
  is not automatically barred when a criminal proceeding is terminated without 
  finally resolving the merits of the charges against the accused.Â  Because of 
  the variety of circumstances that may make it necessary to discharge a jury 
  before a trial is concluded, and because those circumstances do not invariably 
  create unfairness to the accused, his valued right to have the trial concluded 
  by a particular tribunal is sometimes subordinate to the public interest in 
  affording the prosecutor one full and fair opportunity to present his evidence 
  to an impartial jury.

Arizona 
  v. Washington, 434 U.S. 497, 505 (1978).Â  The test to determine whether 
  sound grounds exist for declaring a mistrial after the jury is sworn is â€œwhether 
  the mistrial was dictated by manifest necessity or the ends of public justice, 
  the latter being defined as the publicâ€™s interest in a fair trial designated 
  to end in just judgment.â€Â  State v. Prince, 279 S.C. 30, 33, 301 S.E.2d 
  471, 472 (1983).
â€œManifest 
  necessityâ€ is not a standard that can be applied mechanically or without attention 
  to the particular problem confronting the trial judge.Â  Further, the word â€œnecessityâ€ 
  is not to be interpreted literally.Â  Arizona, 434 U.S. at 505-06.Â  Rather, 
  there need only be a â€œhigh degreeâ€ of necessity in order to conclude that a 
  mistrial is appropriate under the circumstances.Â  Id. at 506.Â  Whether 
  a mistrial is mandated by manifest necessity is a fact specific inquiry.Â  Rowlands, 
  343 S.C. at 457, 539 S.E.2d at 719.Â  Given the â€œvarying and often unique situations 
  arising during the course of a criminal trial,â€ the United States Supreme Court 
  has recognized a broad discretion reserved to a trial judge in declaring a mistrial.Â  
  Kirby, 269 S.C. at 29, 236 S.E.2d at 35 (quoting Illinois v. Somerville, 
  410 U.S. 458, 93 S.Ct. 1066, 35 L.Ed.2d 425 (1973)).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision 
  to grant a mistrial will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion amounting 
  to an error of law.Â  Rowlands, 343 S.C. at 458, 539 S.E.2d at 719.
Baum asserts, 
  however, that the State sought a mistrial to simply marshal evidence to strengthen 
  its case against him, and that the grant of a mistrial on such basis is clearly 
  prohibited by the Double Jeopardy Clause.Â  We agree that, as it has evolved 
  in this country, the prohibition against double jeopardy is intended to condemn 
  the practice of the prosecution requesting a mistrial for the sole purpose of 
  buttressing weakness in its evidence, and the strictest of scrutiny is appropriate 
  when the basis for a mistrial is the unavailability of critical prosecution 
  evidence.Â  Arizona, 434 U.S. at 507-08.Â  However, we do not believe the 
  facts of this case warrant the conclusion that this was the reason behind the 
  granting of the mistrial.Â  
First, we cannot say the body of the victim in this case was critical 
  evidence in the prosecution of Baum such that its unavailability triggers the 
  strict scrutiny announced in Arizona.Â  As noted by Baum, the fact that 
  Randall Pinion had been murdered was not in issue.Â  At any rate, we conclude 
  the discovery of the body of a victim during a murder trial, is an extremely 
  important piece of evidence which has just as much potential to exonerate as 
  to inculpate an accused.Â  The judge recognized as much, and found that the publicâ€™s 
  interest in a fair adjudication was implicated by the possibility of discovering 
  exculpatory evidence and giving the jury the benefit of the fully developed 
  facts when deciding the matter.Â  Consequently, we believe manifest necessity 
  was clearly established, and find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s 
  determination that a mistrial was dictated by such.
For the foregoing reasons, Baumâ€™s conviction is
 
  AFFIRMED.
CONNOR and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

    the jury merely found she was due no money. By not specifically finding against 
    the cooperative, it is apparent the jury found for Mrs. Haskins on the issue 
    of liability but awarded no damages.â€ This court further held that inasmuch 
    as both lawsuits arose out of the same factual situation â€œand the record supports 
    the claim the wife had suffered damages, it is error for the trial judge to 
    refuse to grant a new trial [to the wife] on the issue of the wifeâ€™s damages.â€ 
    Id. at 237, 321 S.E.2d at 190-91.
  Also instructive is the case of Guinn v. Millard 
    Truck Lines, Inc., 134 N.W.2d 549, 555-558 (Iowa 1965). There the wife 
    and the minor child were involved in an automobile accident.Â  The wife, minor 
    child and husband each brought a claim against the truck company and driver.Â Â  
    The wife and minor child sought damages for personal injuries, the husband 
    sued for property damages and medical expenses.Â  The jury returned a verdict 
    in favor of the wife and minor child on their claims, and against the husband 
    on his claim.Â  The trucking company and driver appealed arguing the verdicts 
    were inconsistent and therefore the verdict in favor of the wife should be 
    reversed.Â  The Iowa supreme court held that the verdicts in this case were 
    not irreconcilable.Â Â  The court found that the primary issues in this case 
    were the negligence of the truck driver, and the contributory negligence of 
    the wife.Â  The court found that the juryâ€™s verdict for the wife indicted that 
    the jury determined that the truck driver and company were negligent.Â Â  The 
    court determined that the denial of recovery to the husband was based on his 
    damage claim, and not on the liability issue.Â  The court found that the jury 
    had settled the question of liability fairly and upon sufficient evidence, 
    and therefore, the obvious error in the case was the failure of the jury to 
    award the husband damages. The court rationalized: 



  [T]hat the issue of the [husbandâ€™s] damages was so disassociated 
    from other questions that in the interest of justice [the juryâ€™s] determination 
    of the [wifeâ€™s and daughterâ€™s] causes should stand.Â  [T]o decide that the 
    jury was not aware the issues because it refused to grant [husbandâ€™s] damages 
    seems unjust and needless and penalizes the truly innocent parties.



  In this case, the jury decided the question of Clearyâ€™s 
    liability to both Daves and Jane fairly and upon sufficient facts. The juryâ€™s 
    verdict for Daves clearly implies that it found Cleary negligent and there 
    is abundant evidence to support that finding. The error Cleary claims the 
    trial judge made was in not affording him a new trial on the juryâ€™s award 
    to Daves because a verdict for Daves is inconsistent with the juryâ€™s finding 
    that Cleary is not liable for Janeâ€™s loss of consortium claim. Under the facts 
    of this case, the jury could have found sufficient evidence to have awarded 
    Jane damages, if they had believed her testimony. The jury obviously rejected 
    her testimony, as was theur prerogative. See Craven, 292 S.C. at 443, 
    357 S.E.2d at 25 (â€œThe credibility of witnesses is for the triers of factâ€).Â  
    Unlike the jury in the Haskins v. Fairfield Electric case, it is clear 
    in this matter that when the issue of Janeâ€™s entitlement to an award was resubmitted 
    to the jury, the jury understood that it could not find Cleary was liable 
    to Jane and not award Jane damages. 
    [3] 
  Therefore, we hold the verdicts in this case are not 
    irreconcilably inconsistent such that Cleary is entitled to a new trial.Â  
    Courts must sustain verdicts when a logical reason for reconciling them can 
    be found.Â  Rhodes v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., supra.Â Â Â  
    A juryâ€™s verdict should be affirmed if it is possible to do so and carry into 
    effect the juryâ€™s clear intention.Â Â Â  New York Carpet World v. Houston, 
    292 S.C. 101, 103, 354 S.E.2d 924, 925 (Ct. App. 1987). 
  CONCLUSION
  Based on the foregoing, the rulings by the circuit court 
    and juryâ€™s verdicts are
  AFFIRMED.
   GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  
    Neither the hospital nor the primary physician is a party to this appeal.Â  
  

 
   [2]  
    We think that the better practice is to charge juries in malpractice cases 
    such as this, that in evaluating the conduct of a physician the jury should 
    compare â€œ[the physicianâ€™s actions] to those of a doctor in the same field 
    of medicine.â€Â  Burroughs,Â  352 S.C. at 403,Â  574 S.E. 2dÂ  at 225.

 
   
    [3] We hasten to observe that this case should be distinguished 
    from the case where the jury awards loss of consortium damages to a spouse, 
    but denies damages to the allegedly injured party. Â Â In suchÂ  a case, a new 
    trial is required.Â  See 41 Am. Jur. 2d Husband and WifeÂ  Â§ 258 
    (1995) citing Smith v. Ridgeway Chemicals, Inc., 302 S.C. 303, 
    395 S.E.2d 742 (1990) (â€œGenerally, a plaintiff spouseâ€™s claim for loss of 
    consortium fails if the impaired spouseâ€™s claim fails, whether the claim is 
    considered separate and independent from the impaired spouseâ€™s claim or derivative 
    in nature.â€)

title: State v. Gill
description: Addresses the sufficiency of an indictment to vest subject matter jurisdiction in the trial court and whether defendant waived his right to counsel.

State v. Gill



THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Carlos Miguel Gill, 
          Appellant. 
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John 
  C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3656
Heard April 10, 2003 â€“ Filed June 
  23, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate 
  Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General 
  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
  Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General W. 
  Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM:Â  Carlos M. Gill appeals his convictions for distribution of crack 
  cocaine, distribution of crack cocaine within proximity of a school, and conspiracy 
  to distribute crack cocaine.Â  He argues the trial court (1) lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction on two of the charges because the indictments failed to allege 
  that he â€œknowinglyâ€ committed the offenses and (2) erred in finding he waived 
  his right to have an attorney represent him at trial.Â  We affirm.
BACKGROUND
Undercover police officer William Graham, accompanied by Cora Lee Neil, an acquaintance 
  of Gillâ€™s, made a controlled purchase of $40 worth of crack cocaine from Gill.Â  
  The purchase was video and audio taped and occurred approximately 670 feet from 
  an elementary school.Â  Gill was not represented by counsel at trial.Â  He was 
  convicted as charged, sentenced to twenty-five years imprisonment and a $50,000 
  fine for distribution of crack cocaine; fifteen years and a $10,000 fine for 
  distribution within proximity of a school; and five years for conspiracy, with 
  all sentences to run concurrently.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. SUBJECT MATTER JURISDICTION
Gill argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to try him on 
  the charges of distribution and distribution within the proximity of a school 
  because the indictments failed to allege he â€œknowinglyâ€ committed the acts.Â  
  We disagree.
Gillâ€™s indictment for distribution of crack cocaine alleged that he â€œdid distribute, 
  dispense, or deliver a quantity of crack cocaine . . . or did otherwise aid, 
  abet, attempt, or conspire to distribute, dispense, or deliver crack cocaine, 
  all in violation of Section 44-53-375. . . .â€Â  Section 44-53-375 of the South 
  Carolina Code provides that â€œ[a] person who manufactures, distributes, dispenses, 
  delivers, purchases, or otherwise aids, abets, attempts, or conspires to manufacture, 
  distribute, dispense, deliver, or purchase, or possesses with intent to distribute, 
  dispense, or deliver ice, crank, or crack cocaine, in violation of the provisions 
  of Section 44-53-370, is guilty of a felony.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(B) 
  (2002). 
The indictment for distribution within proximity of a school provided that Gill 
  â€œdid unlawfully distribute a controlled substance, . . . to wit: crack cocaine, 
  within a one-half mile radius of the grounds of York One Academy, a public school 
  located in the city of York, South Carolina, . . . all in violation of Section 
  44-53-445. . . .â€Â  Section 44-53-445 of the South Carolina Code provides it 
  is a separate criminal offense to â€œdistribute, sell, purchase, manufacture, 
  or to unlawfully possess with intent to distribute, a controlled substance while 
  in, on, or within a one-half mile radius of the grounds of a public or private 
  elementary, middle, or secondary school. . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445(A) 
  (2002).
Questions regarding subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.Â  
  Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d 773, 777 (1998); State 
  v. Williams, 346 S.C. 424, 431, 552 S.E.2d 54, 58 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  A trial 
  court acquires subject matter jurisdiction over a criminal matter where â€œthere 
  is an indictment which sufficiently states the offense, the defendant waives 
  presentment, or the offense is a lesser included offense of the crime charged 
  in the indictment.â€Â  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 579, 564 S.E.2d 103, 
  105 (2002); State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 639, 545 S.E.2d 511, 513 (2001); 
  Carter, 329 S.C. at 362, 495 S.E.2d at 777.Â Â Â  

An indictment 
  is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity 
  to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to 
  know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal 
  or conviction thereon.Â  The true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is 
  not whether it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains 
  the necessary elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently 
  apprises the defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.Â  

Browning 
  v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995) (citations omitted); 
  Williams, 346 S.C. at 431-32, 552 S.E.2d at 58; S.C. Code Ann Â§ 17-19-20 
  (2003).
The key question in the underlying case is whether the mens rea element of the 
  crime of distribution of crack cocaine must be alleged in the indictment to 
  confer subject matter jurisdiction.Â  In State v. Ferguson, 302 S.C. 269, 
  395 S.E.2d 182 (1990), our supreme court considered whether a trial court erred 
  in charging the jury regarding the mental state necessary to be proved for conviction 
  of certain crimes.Â  The Ferguson court noted that the required mental 
  state to be proven by the State on a certain offense may include purpose or 
  knowledge.Â  Id. at 271, 395 S.E.2d at 183.Â  The court then noted the 
  legislature could make an act or omission a crime â€œregardless of fault,â€ or 
  could make a particular crime a strict liability crime.Â  Id. at 271-72, 
  395 S.E.2d at 183.Â  Reviewing the trial courtâ€™s jury instructions regarding 
  the mental element of distribution of cocaine and the legislative intent behind 
  section 44-53-370, the court held distribution was not a strict liability crime 
  and the State was required to prove the defendant was at least criminally negligent.Â  
  Id. at 272-73, 395 S.E.2d at 184.Â  
Two recent 
  cases have also discussed the elements of distribution of crack cocaine.Â  In 
  State v. Watts, 321 S.C. 158, 467 S.E.2d 272 (Ct. App. 1996), this court 
  reviewed whether a variance in the proof and the allegations in an indictment 
  for distribution of crack cocaine warranted a directed verdict in favor of the 
  defendant.Â  We noted as follows:

The essential elements 
  of the offense of distribution of crack cocaine which the court charged the 
  jury the State was required to prove were: (1) Watts had actual control, or 
  the right to exercise control over the crack cocaine; (2) he knowingly distributed 
  or delivered the crack cocaine; (3) the substance upon analysis was, in fact, 
  crack cocaine; and (4) the offense occurred in Greenwood County.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375 (Supp. 1994).Â  The charge of distribution of crack 
  cocaine within one-half mile of a school required the same proof with an additional 
  element that the distribution occurred within a one-half mile radius of the 
  grounds of an elementary, middle, or secondary school.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 44-53-445 (Supp. 1994). 

Id. 
  at 168, 467 S.E.2d at 278.Â  Because the indictment in Watts listed the 
  wrong accomplice, but the State submitted proof regarding the correct accomplice 
  and all elements of the crime, we held there was no material variance, the listed 
  co-defendant was mere surplusage, and the defendant was not entitled to a directed 
  verdict.Â  Id. 
More recently in Brown v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 540 S.E.2d 846 (2001), 
  our state supreme court addressed whether the trial court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction over a charge of distribution within proximity of a school where 
  the indictment alleged the distribution occurred near a daycare center.Â  The 
  court noted:

To prove distribution 
  of crack cocaine under [S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-445 (Supp. 1992)], the State 
  must establish the following elements:Â  (1) the defendant had actual control, 
  or the right to exercise control over the crack cocaine; (2) he knowingly distributed 
  or delivered the crack cocaine; (3) the substance upon analysis was, in fact, 
  crack cocaine; and (4) the distribution occurred within a one-half mile radius 
  of the grounds of an elementary, middle, secondary or vocational school; public 
  playground or park; or college or university.Â  See id.; State 
  v. Watts, 321 S.C. 158, 168, 467 S.E.2d 272, 278 (Ct. App. 1996). 

Id. 
  at 347-48, 540 S.E.2d at 849.Â  Because daycare centers were not listed in the 
  statute by the legislature, our supreme court held the indictment failed to 
  include a necessary element of the offense and the trial court did not have 
  jurisdiction over the matter.Â  Id. at 349-50, 540 S.E.2d at 850.Â  
In the underlying case, Gillâ€™s indictment for distribution alleged that on February 
  1, 2000, he distributed crack cocaine or aided, abetted, attempted or conspired 
  to distribute crack cocaine in violation of Section 44-53-375.Â  His indictment 
  for the proximity charge alleged Gill distributed crack cocaine within a one-half 
  mile radius of York One Academy, a South Carolina public school, in violation 
  of Section 44-53-445 on the same date.Â  Both indictments listed the elements 
  of the crime found in the respective statutes.Â  The indictments sufficiently 
  informed Gill he had to defend against charges of distribution of crack cocaine 
  and distribution near York One Academy on February 1, 2000.Â  Clearly, the indictments 
  were sufficient to inform Gill about the charges he faced and what he must defend 
  against.Â  
With regard to Gillâ€™s allegations that the indictments must allege that he â€œknowinglyâ€ 
  distributed the drugs, we note neither Section 44-53-375 nor Section 44-53-445 
  includes â€œknowinglyâ€ as an element of the crime.Â  Although Ferguson, 
  Watts, and Brown list â€œknowinglyâ€ as an element the State must 
  prove for the crime of distribution, none of these cases addressed whether the 
  â€œknowinglyâ€ element must be alleged in the indictment in order to convey subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  Upon closer scrutiny, we find they can be read to mean 
  that â€œknowinglyâ€ is merely an element the State must prove to obtain a conviction.Â  
  If the General Assembly intended a mens rea element in the crimes of distribution 
  and distribution within proximity of a school to be necessary to convey jurisdiction, 
  the requirement would have been listed in the statute.Â  Accordingly, reading 
  the indictments and statutes as a whole, we find the indictments contained the 
  elements necessary to convey jurisdiction, and Gill was sufficiently apprised 
  of the crimes against him.Â  
II. WAIVER OF ATTORNEY
Gill argues the trial court erred in finding he waived his right to an attorney 
  and in failing to inquire whether he qualified for a public defender.Â  We disagree. 
  
Gill applied for appointment of a public defender on April 17, 2000, while he 
  was free on bond for the underlying charges.Â  Because Gill was gainfully employed 
  at the time, he was rejected as non-indigent.Â  Gill repeatedly assured the assistant 
  solicitor that he intended to hire a private attorney, but failed to do so.Â  
  Gill also failed to appear for a court date and was incarcerated pursuant to 
  a bench warrant on July 26, 2000.Â  
On August 11, 2000, a hearing was held before the trial court concerning Gillâ€™s 
  lack of representation.Â  The assistant solicitor stated she wanted an attorney 
  on the other side of the case and informed the court that she had encouraged 
  Gill to fill out another application for a public defender.Â  The trial judge 
  informed Gill that his trial date was August 21, 2000, and inquired whether 
  Gill would like to apply for a public defender.Â  The following exchange then 
  occurred:

Mr. Gill:Â  My girlfriend, 
  I had a visit yesterday.Â  Hopefully, everything going all right.Â  She was supposed 
  to meet with him today.Â  I told [Assistant Solicitor] I would get back with 
  her sometime and let her know.Â  I supposed to be getting Stacy Lewis, so when 
  I call her today, Iâ€™ll know something for sure.Â  
The Court:Â  All 
  right. Youâ€™re up for trial with or without an attorney the week of the twenty-first 
  of this month.Â  Weâ€™re not going to put off the trial for you to get a lawyer.Â  
  Youâ€™ve either got to get one or â€“ you havenâ€™t applied for a public defender, 
  so, we canâ€™t appoint you one.Â  But we canâ€™t keep rocking along without a trial 
  being disposed of.Â  Do you understand that?
Mr. Gill:Â  
  Yes sir.Â  
The Court:Â  
  Do you have any questions? 
Mr. Gill:Â  No sir.Â  
  

Because the State was trying other cases, Gillâ€™s case was not called the week 
  of August 21, 2000.Â  Gill requested a hearing before the trial judge on August 
  24, 2000, to discuss whether the bench warrant against him should have been 
  issued.Â  During the hearing, the assistant solicitor expressed her concern that 
  Gill still did not have representation.Â  Gill told the trial judge he had $800 
  of the $1,000 needed to retain Stacy Lewis as an attorney, but he could not 
  earn the remaining money if the trial judge did not allow him out on bond so 
  he could return to work.Â  The trial court refused to withdraw the bench warrant 
  and free Gill.Â  
Gillâ€™s trial began September 12, 2000.Â  Before the trial began, Gill informed 
  the trial judge that the assistant solicitor prevented him from getting an attorney, 
  even though Gillâ€™s family had the money to pay Lewis.Â  The trial judge called 
  attorney Lewis on the speaker telephone to determine whether Gill had actually 
  retained his services.Â  Lewis denied that he represented Gill.Â  He explained 
  that Gillâ€™s girlfriend was supposed to bring a retainer fee by 3:00 the previous 
  afternoon, but she failed to do so until after 3:30, when Lewis had left the 
  office.Â  Lewis stated he had â€œhad it with them,â€ and admitted the assistant 
  solicitor informed him the trial judge would not likely grant a continuance 
  in the case because Gill had been informed to be prepared for trial with or 
  without an attorney.Â  Noting that Gill had â€œplenty of timeâ€ in which to retain 
  counsel, the trial judge informed Gill that his trial would proceed without 
  an attorney, finding as follows:

I find that the 
  Court and the solicitorâ€™s office both ha[ve] done all possible to assist and 
  urge Mr. Gill to obtain counsel and he has not so done.Â  I find no showing why 
  he has not retained counsel other than he just hadnâ€™t chose[n] to pay him according 
  to what Mr. Lewisâ€™ comments were, so I find that he has waived his right to 
  counsel and he is to proceed to trial without an attorney.Â  

During 
  the trial, the court further noted that:

The court has after 
  due deliberation prior to commencing the trial made a conscious decision not 
  to appoint the public defender or anyone else to assist Mr. Gill as is sometimes 
  done in cases of this type.Â  The court did not want to put counsel in that position 
  and the court finds there is no way any counsel could be prepared to do, to 
  appoint counsel under these circumstances is somewhat inconsistent with finding 
  that Mr. Gill has waived his right to counsel.Â  

Gill complained 
  that he was being denied his rights, that he needed an attorney, and that his 
  family had the money to hire one for him.Â  
The court 
  proceeded with the trial.Â  Gill continued to protest his lack of representation 
  and refused to participate in jury selection or opening statements.Â  After Gill 
  questioned the judge regarding his rights, the judge informed the jury that 
  Gill was given the right to get an attorney.Â  Gill continued to object that 
  his rights had been violated and he had not been given an attorney throughout 
  the trial.Â  At one point, Gill interrupted Neilâ€™s testimony to state that she 
  smokes crack.Â  He then complained the court was â€œrailroadingâ€ him because the 
  court failed to appoint a public defender to defend him, and he requested to 
  be taken out of the courtroom into the holding cell.Â  The judge allowed Gill 
  to be taken to the holding cell, and he admonished the jury not to consider 
  his absence against him in any manner.Â  The trial continued with the State calling 
  three more witnesses while Gill was in the holding cell.Â  After the State rested, 
  Gill was brought back into the courtroom and chose not to present any evidence.Â  
  During his closing argument, Gill continued to complain that the court had â€œtakenâ€ 
  all his rights away by preventing him from getting an attorney, despite the 
  fact that his family had the money to hire one.Â  
The Sixth 
  Amendment guarantees criminal defendants a right to counsel.Â  U.S. Const. amend. 
  VI.; Stevenson v. State, 337 S.C. 23, 26, 522 S.E.2d 343, 344 (1999).Â  
  This right may be waived.Â  State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 241, 523 S.E.2d 
  168, 170 (1999).Â  A waiver may be inferred from the defendantâ€™s actions.Â  State 
  v. Cain, 277 S.C. 210, 210-11, 284 S.E.2d 779 (1981).Â  
In State 
  v. Jacobs, our supreme court considered whether a criminal defendant waived 
  his right to counsel through his conduct rather than by express waiver.Â  Jacobs, 
  271 S.C. 126, 245 S.E.2d 606 (1978).Â  In that case, Ray Jacobs surrendered himself 
  on May 23, 1977, pursuant to an arrest warrant for possession and sale of marijuana.Â  
  The trial court found him non-indigent and advised him to hire an attorney.Â  
  On several occasions, the court urged Jacobs to retain counsel and continued 
  the case at least once because Jacobs had not yet done so.Â  At one point prior 
  to trial, Jacobs informed the court he had counsel, but the record did not reveal 
  the accuracy of this claim.Â  Jacobsâ€™ trial was held on June 2. Â Jacobs appeared 
  without counsel, but informed the court that his brother was supposed to bring 
  counsel and that he had been waiting on him to make the arrangements.Â  The court 
  offered to get the attorney into court, but Jacobs did not provide a name or 
  a time when he expected to have retained counsel.Â  The court then ruled Jacobs 
  had waived his right to counsel and asked a public defender to sit with him 
  to offer advice and assistance.Â  Id. at 127, 245 S.E.2d at 607.Â  On appeal, 
  our supreme court held Jacobs had been granted â€œa reasonable time in which to 
  retain counsel andÂ  . . . did not make a sufficient showing of reasons for his 
  failure to have counsel present.â€Â  Id. at 128, 245 S.E.2d at 608.Â  Thus, 
  the court reasoned, Jacobs had, â€œby his conductâ€ waived his right to counsel.Â  
  Id.Â  Therefore, the court refused to consider the adequacy of the assistance 
  provided him by the public defender who sat with him during the trial.Â  Id.Â  
  
In State 
  v. Cain, Larry Cain was tried in absentia and without counsel for 
  driving under the influence, third offense.Â  Cain, 277 S.C. 210, 284 
  S.E.2d 779 (1981).Â  On appeal from his conviction, Cain argued the trial court 
  could not infer a valid waiver of his right to counsel by his failure to appear 
  at trial.Â  Our supreme court disagreed, noting Cain was released on a general 
  appearance bond and was represented by counsel at a preliminary hearing and 
  that both Cain and his counsel knew about the upcoming trial, but failed to 
  appear.Â  Id. at 210-11, 284 S.E.2d at 779.Â  The court held Cainâ€™s waiver 
  of counsel was inferable by his failure to fulfill his appearance bond conditions 
  and his failure to keep in contact with his counsel.Â  Id. 
In the present case, Gill repeatedly assured the trial judge that either he 
  or his family had the money to retain counsel.Â  Even when the trial judge inquired 
  whether he wanted to apply for a public defender, Gill continued to claim that 
  he intended to hire private counsel.Â  At two pre-trial hearings, the State and 
  the trial court discussed their concerns regarding Gillâ€™s lack of counsel.Â  
  However, between Gillâ€™s April 17, 2000 arrest and his September 2000 trial, 
  Gill failed to obtain counsel.Â  Although Gill never expressly waived his right 
  to counsel, the trial court found it did all it could to urge Gill to obtain 
  counsel.Â  Gill was allowed a reasonable time in which to hire counsel.Â  Based 
  on Gillâ€™s actions, we find a waiver of counsel may be inferred.Â  Id.; 
  Jacobs, 271 S.C. at 128, 245 S.E.2d at 608.Â  
 
  AFFIRMED.
 STILWELL 
  and HOWARD, JJ. and STROM, Acting Judge, concur.

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviewing the decision to issue a search warrant should 
  decide whether the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding probable 
  cause existed.Â  State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 
  2002); State v. Arnold, 319 S.C. 256, 460 S.E.2d 403 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
  This review, like the determination by the magistrate, is governed by the â€œtotality 
  of the circumstancesâ€ test.Â  State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 121, 536 S.E.2d 
  675 (2000); King, 349 S.C. at 148, 561 S.E.2d at 643.Â  The appellate 
  court should give great deference to a magistrateâ€™s determination of probable 
  cause.Â  Jones, 342 S.C. at 126, 536 S.E.2d at 678; State v. Dunbar, 
  Op. No. 3631 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 21, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 15 
  at 44) (Anderson, J., dissenting); King, 349 S.C. at 148, 561 S.E.2d 
  at 643.
Affidavits are not meticulously drawn by lawyers, but are normally drafted 
  by non-lawyers in the haste of a criminal investigation, and should therefore 
  be viewed in a common sense and realistic fashion.Â  State v. Sullivan, 
  267 S.C. 610, 230 S.E.2d 621 (1976); Arnold, 319 S.C. at 260, 460 S.E.2d 
  at 405.Â  Our task is to decide whether the magistrate had a substantial basis 
  for concluding probable cause existed.Â  State v. Adolphe, 314 S.C. 89, 
  441 S.E.2d 832 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The term â€œprobable causeâ€ does not import absolute 
  certainty.Â  State v. Bennett, 256 S.C. 234, 182 S.E.2d 291 (1971); Arnold, 
  319 S.C. at 260, 460 S.E.2d at 405.Â  Rather, in determining whether a search 
  warrant should be issued, magistrates are concerned with probabilities and not 
  certainties.Â  Sullivan, 267 S.C. at 617, 230 S.E.2d at 624.Â  Searches 
  based on warrants will be given judicial deference to the extent that an otherwise 
  marginal search may be justified if it meets a realistic standard of probable 
  cause.Â  Bennett, 256 S.C. at 241, 182 S.E.2d at 294; Arnold, 319 
  S.C. at 260, 460 S.E.2d at 405.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  VALIDITY OF SEARCH 
  WARRANT
Dupree contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress 
  evidence obtained as a result of the search of the mobile home.Â  Specifically, 
  Dupree maintains the search warrant affidavit and additional information provided 
  to the magistrate did not support a finding of probable cause because the State 
  failed to (1) demonstrate the reliability of the confidential informant and 
  (2) provide any specific factual detail concerning what had transpired or been 
  observed when the informant was in the residence.Â  We disagree.
A magistrate may issue a search warrant only upon a finding of probable cause.Â  
  State v. Tench, 353 S.C. 531, 579 S.E.2d 314 (2003); State v. Weston, 
  329 S.C. 287, 494 S.E.2d 801 (1997); State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 561 
  S.E.2d 640 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThe South Carolina General Assembly has enacted 
  a requirement that search warrants may be issued â€˜only upon affidavit sworn 
  to before the magistrate . . . establishing the grounds for the warrant.â€™â€Â  
  State v. Bellamy, 336 S.C. 140, 143, 519 S.E.2d 347, 348 (1999) (quoting 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (1985)).
The affidavit must contain sufficient underlying facts and information upon 
  which the magistrate may make a determination of probable cause.Â  State v. 
  Philpot, 317 S.C. 458, 454 S.E.2d 905 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The magistrate should 
  determine probable cause based on all of the information available to the magistrate 
  at the time the warrant was issued.Â  State v. Driggers, 322 S.C. 506, 
  473 S.E.2d 57 (Ct. App. 1996); State v. Bultron, 318 S.C. 323, 457 S.E.2d 
  616 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In determining the validity of the warrant, a reviewing 
  court may consider only information brought to the magistrateâ€™s attention.Â  
  State v. Owen, 275 S.C. 586, 274 S.E.2d 510 (1981); State v. Martin, 
  347 S.C. 522, 556 S.E.2d 706 (Ct. App. 2001).
The United States Supreme Court, in Illinois v. Gates, 462 
  U.S. 213 (1983), rejected the application of a rigid two-pronged test in which 
  an informantâ€™s veracity and basis of knowledge were considered as separate and 
  independent requirements to finding probable cause.Â  Weston, 329 S.C. 
  at 290, 494 S.E.2d at 802.Â  â€œInstead, the Court adopted a totality of the circumstances 
  test where veracity and basis of knowledge were relevant to, but not inflexible 
  requirements of, a determination of probable cause.â€Â  Id.Â  The magistrateâ€™s 
  task in determining whether to issue a search warrant is to make a practical, 
  common sense decision concerning whether, under the totality of the circumstances 
  set forth in the affidavit, including the veracity and basis of knowledge of 
  persons supplying hearsay information, there is a fair probability that contraband 
  or evidence of a crime will be found in the particular place to be searched.Â  
  Gates, 462 U.S. at 238; Tench, 353 S.C. at Â Â Â , 579 S.E.2d 
  at 316; Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 143, 519 S.E.2d at 348; King, 349 
  S.C. at 150, 561 S.E.2d at 644; see also State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 
  121, 536 S.E.2d 675 (2000) (under totality of circumstances test, reviewing 
  court considers all circumstances, including status, basis of knowledge, and 
  veracity of informant, when determining whether or not probable cause existed 
  to issue search warrant).Â  Under this formula, veracity and basis of knowledge 
  are treated â€œas closely intertwined issues that may usefully illuminate the 
  commonsense, practical question whether there is â€˜probable causeâ€™ to believe 
  that contraband or evidence is located in a particular place.â€Â  Gates, 
  462 U.S. at 230.Â  These are relevant considerations in the totality of the circumstances 
  analysis.Â  Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 144, 519 S.E.2d at 349.
A deficiency in one of the elements of veracity and reliability may be compensated 
  for, in determining the overall reliability of a tip, by a strong showing as 
  to the other, or by some other indicia of reliability.Â  Gates, 462 U.S. 
  at 233; Bellamy, 336 S.C. at 144, 519 S.E.2d at 349; Martin, 347 
  S.C. at 527-28, 556 S.E.2d at 709.Â  The Gates case enunciated the following 
  examples of the interaction of the relevant considerations:

If, for example, a particular informant is known for the 
  unusual reliability of his predictions of certain types of criminal activities 
  in a locality, his failure, in a particular case, to thoroughly set forth the 
  basis of his knowledge surely should not serve as an absolute bar to a finding 
  of probable cause based on his tip.Â  Likewise, if an unquestionably honest citizen 
  comes forward with a report of criminal activity--which if fabricated would 
  subject him to criminal liability--we have found rigorous scrutiny of the basis 
  of his knowledge unnecessary.Â  Conversely, even if we entertain some doubt as 
  to an informantâ€™s motives, his explicit and detailed description of alleged 
  wrongdoing, along with a statement that the event was observed firsthand, entitles 
  his tip to greater weight than might otherwise be the case.

Gates, 462 U.S. at 233-34 (citations omitted).
State v. Viard, 276 S.C. 147, 276 S.E.2d 531 (1981), although decided 
  under the more stringent pre-Gates standard, is instructive.Â  In Viard, 
  a confidential informant made a controlled buy of drugs at the residence of 
  the Viards.Â  Id. at 148, 276 S.E.2d at 532.Â  The residence was searched, 
  pursuant to a warrant, and a quantity of drugs seized.Â  Id. at 148-49, 
  276 S.E.2d at 532.Â  The trial judge granted the Viardsâ€™ motion to suppress the 
  drugs, holding the affidavit supporting the search warrant did not contain information 
  about the informantâ€™s reliability and failed to set forth sufficient underlying

  Id. at 149, 276 S.E.2d at 532.Â  The Supreme Court, applying the more 
  strict pre-Gates test, reversed the trial courtâ€™s grant of the Viardsâ€™ 
  motion to suppress the drugs.Â  The Court explained:

  Although reliability may be established by the informant having previously

  of the information, prior to the search.Â  See: State v. Camargo, 
  23 Ariz. App. 47, 530 P.2d 893 (1975); State v. Bullard, 267 N.C. 599, 
  148 S.E.2d 565 (1966).
Here, the warrant must be upheld not on the basis of the past credibility of 
  the informant, but upon the independent verification of facts by the affiant.Â  
  The information furnished by the informant taken as a whole in the light of 
  all of the circumstances disclosed is reliable.Â  Moreover, the controlled buy 
  was evidence of the credibility and trustworthiness of the informant.Â  See: 
  Camargo, supra; Tamburino v. Commonwealth, 218 Va. 821, 
  241 S.E.2d 762 (1978).
Although the affidavit was inartfully drawn, a common-sense reading of it supports 
  the magistrateâ€™s finding of probable cause.Â  Affiant alleged his informant had 
  been at the residence, saw drugs there within the past 72 hours, and purchased 
  drugs during a controlled buy which field tested positive for depressants.Â  
  We conclude the affidavit contained sufficient underlying facts and information 
  upon which the magistrate made her independent determination of probable cause.

Viard, 276 S.C. at 150-51, 276 S.E.2d at 532.
Furthermore, the case of United States v. Smith, 914 F.2d 565 (4th Cir. 
  1990), is illustrative.Â  The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals articulated:

Smith challenges the search of his motel room by asserting that there was a 
  lack of probable cause . . . .
Smith attacks the conclusory nature of the affidavit, specifically asserting

Smith, 914 F.2d at 568.
An informantâ€™s controlled buy of drugs can constitute probable cause sufficient 
  for a magistrate to issue a warrant.Â  See United States v. Clyburn, 
  24 F.3d 613 (4th Cir. 1994); see also United States v. Cook, 949 
  F.2d 289 (10th Cir. 1991) (finding probable cause where informant was searched 
  for money and drugs, was given money and seen to enter defendantâ€™s apartment,

  (declaring that controlled buy established probable cause where officer searched

  v. Sherlock, 768 P.2d 1290 (Haw. 1989) (holding affidavit was sufficient

  787 P.2d 711 (Kan. 1990) (ruling judge had substantial basis for concluding 
  probable cause existed to issue search warrant where informant was searched

  489 A.2d 529 (Me. 1985) (noting that controlled buy was sufficient corroboration 
  under Gates even though affidavit failed to describe in explicit detail 
  the police surveillance of informant during controlled buy); Commonwealth 
  v. Warren, 635 N.E.2d 240, 242 (Mass. 1994) (stating â€œ[a] controlled purchase 
  of narcotics, supervised by the police, provides probable cause to issue a search 
  warrantâ€); Commonwealth v. Hill, 747 N.E.2d 1241, 1250 n.9 (Mass. App. 
  Ct. 2001) (emphasizing that a controlled buy is â€œone of the most significant

  356 N.W.2d 671 (Minn. 1984) (observing that controlled buy was sufficient corroboration

In Search and Seizure: A Treatise on the Fourth Amendment, Wayne R. 
  LaFave illuminates:

[A] situation in which the corroboration will suffice to show veracity is that 
  in which the informant has not been working independently, but rather has cooperated 
  closely with the police, as is true when the informant makes a controlled purchase

  in the informantâ€™s intrigueâ€ by the police, so that it is not â€œindependent police 
  workâ€ which corroborates, but rather â€œthe police corroboration is a co-ordinant 
  and intrinsic part of the informerâ€™s operation,â€ the risk of falsehood has been

  621, 625 (Vt. 1974)]:
  
The purpose of the search of the informer and his being escorted to the place

2 Wayne R. LaFave, Search and Seizure: A Treatise on the Fourth Amendment 
  Â§ 3.3(f) (3d ed. 1996) (footnotes omitted).
If the controlled buy was properly conducted, it alone can provide facts sufficient 
  to establish probable cause for a search warrant.Â  See Hignut v. State, 
  303 A.2d 173, 180 (Md. Ct. Spec. App. 1973) (â€œSo long as the controls are adequate,

The controlled buy supervised by law enforcement officers would alone have provided

  veracity of an informant or the basis of his knowledge, a tip may be proved

  witnessed the delivery of the cocaine and confirmed the accuracy of many of 
  the informantâ€™s predictions concerning Davisâ€™s behavior.Â  This â€œsufficiently 
  corroboratedâ€ the informantâ€™s information and showed its reliability.

Davis, 568 S.E.2d at 165 (citations omitted).Â  Where the affidavit is 
  based in part on information provided by an informant of unknown reliability,

  Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213 (1983); cf. State v. 192 Coin-Operated

Based on the totality of the circumstances, we hold the affidavit provided 
  the magistrate with a substantial basis for finding probable cause to search 
  the mobile home.Â  State v. Weston, 329 S.C. 287, 494 S.E.2d 801 (1997) 
  (duty of reviewing court is simply to ensure that magistrate had substantial 
  basis for concluding that probable cause existed).Â  Although the affidavit provides 
  the informant is a first-time informant, there are sufficient other indicators 
  of the reliability of his statements.Â  See Gates, 462 U.S. at 
  233 (deficiency in one of elements of veracity and reliability may be compensated 
  for, in determining overall reliability of a tip, by strong showing of basis 
  of knowledge or by some other indicia of reliability).Â  The information provided 
  by the confidential informant was corroborated by the independent police investigation.Â  
  The affidavit indicated that Deputy Mullineaux had conducted an independent 
  investigation by setting up the controlled buy.Â  Deputy Mullineaux searched 
  the informant prior to the controlled buy at the mobile home.Â  At this time, 
  the informant had no drugs on his person.Â  The officer observed the informant 
  enter and exit the mobile home.Â  When the informant returned, Deputy Mullineaux 
  searched him again.Â  At this time, the informant was in possession of crack 
  cocaine and reported obtaining the crack cocaine in the mobile home for which 
  the warrant was obtained.Â  This amounts to sufficient police corroboration of 
  an informantâ€™s information based on the controlled buy.Â  See United 
  States v. Clyburn, 24 F.3d 613 (4th Cir. 1994) (clarifying that an informantâ€™s 
  controlled buy of crack cocaine constituted probable cause for issuance of a 
  search warrant); United States v. Martin, 920 F.2d 393 (6th Cir. 1990) 
  (rejecting defendantâ€™s claim that the informant was unreliable on the ground 
  that the informantâ€™s charges had been verified through a controlled buy of cocaine).Â  
  The affidavit advised that an informant had made a controlled purchase of crack 
  cocaine from the mobile home.Â  The affidavit clearly states the confidential 
  informant was observed entering the mobile home with no crack cocaine in his 
  possession, exiting the mobile home, and then turning over the crack cocaine 
  to Deputy Mullineaux.Â  The controlled buy was evidence of the credibility and 
  trustworthiness of the informant.Â  Furthermore, when the officers executed the 
  search warrant, they did in fact find crack cocaine.
In the affidavit, Deputy Mullineaux noted: â€œBased on the affiantâ€™s and other 
  Richland County Sheriffâ€™s Department narcotic agents experience in drug enforcement, 
  it is known that subjects present at the scene of illegal drug distribution 
  and/or possession commonly have drugs in their possession . . . .â€Â  â€œ[E]vidence 
  of a sale of drugs supports an inference that more will be found at the place 
  of operation.â€Â  State v. Maffeo, 642 P.2d 404, 406 (Wash. Ct. App. 1982) 
  (citing 1 Wayne R. LaFave, Search and Seizure Â§ 3.7 (1978); United 
  States v. Valenzuela, 596 F.2d 824 (9th Cir. 1979)).
Under these facts, a substantial basis existed to support the magistrateâ€™s 
  finding of probable cause.Â  The magistrate had ample probable cause to issue 
  the warrant.Â  Given all the circumstances set forth in the affidavit, there 
  was a â€œfair probabilityâ€ that crack cocaine would be found in the mobile home.Â  
  See Gates, 462 U.S. at 238.Â  Concomitantly, the court did not 
  err in denying Dupreeâ€™s motion to suppress the crack cocaine.
We hold that if a controlled buy is properly conducted, the controlled 
  buy alone can provide facts sufficient to establish probable cause 
  for a search warrant.

Dupree complains the circuit court judge erred in sentencing him

The State requested the court treat the trafficking conviction as a second

A.Â  Statutory Authority:
